div.p: A NEW WONDER, A WOMAN NEVER VEXT.
A PLEASANT CONCEITED Comedy: sundry times Acted: never before printed.
Written by WILLIAM ROWLEY, one of his Maiesties Servants.
LONDON, Imprinted by G. P. for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the Crane in Saint Pauls Churchyard. 1632.

div.head: A NEW WONDER, A WOMAN NEVER VEXT.
Actus Primus.
div.stage: Enter Old Foster, Alderman Bruyne and two Factors Ri-chard chard, and George

sp.speaker: Old Foster.
sp.l: THis ayre has a sweet a breath Master Bruyne.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Your partner Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I, and in good I hope, this halcion gale
sp.p: Playes the lewd wanton with our dancing sayles,
sp.l: And makes 'm big with vaporous envy.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Tis no more yet, but then our fraught is full
When shee returnes laden with merchandize
And safe deliver'd with our customage.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Such a delivery heaven send us,
But time must ripen it? are our accounts made even?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: To the quantity of a penny, if his agree with mines
What's yours Richard?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Five hundred sixty pounds;
Read the grosse summe of your broade cloathes.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.l: 68. peices at B, ss, and l; 57. at 1; ss, and o.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Iust; leade, xix tunne.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: As evenly we will lay our bosomes as our bottomes
With love as merchandise, and may they both increase
to Infinites.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Especially at home; that golden traffique love
Is scantier far than gold; and one myne of that
More worth than twenty Argoseyes
Of the worlds richest treasure.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Here you shall dig, and finde your lading.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Here's your exchange; and as in love
So wee'le participate in merchandize.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The merchants casualty:
We alwayes venture on uncertaine ods,
Altho we beare hopes Embleme the anchor with us.
The winde brought it, let the wind blow't away agen;
Should not the Sea sometimes be partner with us
Our wealth would swallow us.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: A good resolve: but now I must be bold
To touch you with somewhat that concernes you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I could prevent you; is't not my unthrifty brother?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Nay, leave out the adjective (unthrifty,)
Your brother Sir, tis he that I would speake of.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: He cannot be nam'd without unthrifty Sir,
its his proper Epithite, would you conceite
But what my love has done for him
So oft, so chargeable, and so expensive,
You would not urge another addition.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Nay Sir, you must not stay at quantity
Till he forfeitthe name of brother
Which is inseparable, hee's now in Ludgate Sir,
And part of your treasure lyes buryed with him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I, by vulgar blemish; but not by any good account;
There let him howle, as the best stay he hath;
For nothing but a prison can containe him
So boundlesse is his ryot; twice have I raysde
His decayed fortunes to a faire estate
But with as fruitlesse charity, as if I had throwne
My safe landed substance backe into the Sea,
Or dresse in pitty some corrupted Iade,
And he should kick me for my courtesie.
I am sure you cannot but heare, what quicke.
Sands he findes out, as Dice, Cards, Pigeon-holes,
And which is more, should I not restraine it,
Hee'd make my state his prodigality.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: All this may be Sir, yet examples dayly shew
To our eyes, that Prodigalls returne at last
And the lowdest roarer, (as our Citty phrase is)
Will speake calme and smooth; you must helpe with hope Sir,
Had I such a brother, I should thinke that heaven had
Made him as an instrument for my best charity
To worke upon; This is a Maxime sure, Some
Are made poore, that rich men by giving may
Encrease their store. Nor thinke Sir, that I doe
Tax your labors and meane my selfe for to stand
Idlely by, for I have vowd if heaven but blesse
This voyage now abroad, to leave some
Memorable relique after me, that shall
Preserve my name alive till Doomesday.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I Sir, that worke is good, and therein could I
Ioyne with your good intents, but to releeve
A wast-good, a spendthrift.â€”

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: O no more, no more good Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sirra, when saw you my son Robert?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: This morning Sir, he said he would goe visit his Vncle

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I pay for their meetings I'me sure; that boy
Makes prize of all his fingers light on
To releeve his unthrifty Vncle.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Does he rob, introth I commend him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Tis partly your fault, Sirra you see't, and suffer it,

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Sir, mine's a servants duty, his a sonnes,
Nor know I better how to expresse my love
Vnto your selfe, than by loving your son.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: By concealing of his pilferings.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I dare not call them so; he is my second Master,
And methinkes tis far above my limits
Either to checke, or to complaine of him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Gramercy Dick, thou mak'st a good construction,
And your son Robert a naturall Nephewes part.
To releeve his poore Vncle.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Tis in neither well; Sir, for note but the
Condition of my estate; I'me lately marryed
To a wealthy Widow from whom my substance
Chiefely does arise, she has observed this in her
Son in law often complaines and grudges at it,
And what foule broyles such civill discords bring,
Few married men are ignorant of:
Nay will you see a present proofe of it.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I not live to breath a quiet houre?
I would I were a beggar with content
Rather than thus be thwarted for mine owne.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why what's the matter Woman?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: I'le rowse 'm up, tho you regard not of my just complaints
sp.l: Neither in love to me, nor preserving me from others
Injuries, both which y'are tyed to, by all the rightfull
Lawes heavenly or humane, but Ile complaine
Sir, where I will be heard.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, thou'lt be heard too farre.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay Sir, I will be heard; some awkeward starre
Threw out his unhappy fire at my conception
And twill never quench while I have heate in me:
Would I were cold, there would be bonefires made
To warme defame, my death would be a Iubilee to some.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: Why Sir, how should I minister remedy and know not the cause.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Mother a pearle, woman, shew your husband the cause,

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: Had he bin a husband Sir, I had had no cause to Complaine, I threw downe at his feete
sp.l: The subjection of his whole estate:
He did not marry me for loves sake nor for pitty,
But love to that I had, he now neglects the love
He had before; A prodigall is suffer'd to lay waste
Those worldly blessings, which I long enclosde,
Intending for good uses.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: That's my sonne.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: I, thou knowest it well enough, hee's the Conduit pipe that throwes it forth into the common shore.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And the other's my brother.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: You may well shame, as I doe grieve the kindred,
But I'de make the one a stranger, the other a servant,
No son, nor brother; For they deserve neither
Of those offices.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why did I ever cherish him, have not I threatened
Him with disinheritance for this disorder?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why doe you not performe it?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The other's in Ludgate.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No; hee's in my house, approving to my face
The charitable office of his kinde Nephew,
Who with his pilfering purloind from me,
Has set him at liberty; if this may be suffer'd
Ile have no eyes to see.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Prethee content thy selfe; Ile see a present
Remedy; sirra, go call 'm in; this worthy
Gentleman shall know the cause, and censure
For us both with equity.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Nay good Sir, let not me be so imployd,
For I shall favour one for pitty, the other for your loves sake,

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Now Sir, are all my words with you
So light esteem'd that they can
Take no hold upon your duty?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Misconster not, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, heele approve his good deeds I warrant you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And you Sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I had thought you had bin in Ludgate Sir.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Why, you see where I am Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost
sp.l: Why, where are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: In debt Sir, in debt.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Indeed that's a place you can hardly be remou'd
From, but this is not a place fit for one in
Debt, how came you out of prison Sirra?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: As I went into prison Sirra, by the keepers.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: This was your worke to let this bandog loose.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir it was my duty to let my Vncle loose.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Your duty did belong to me, and I did not command

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You cannot make a separation Sir, betwixt
The duty that belongs to me, and love unto
My Vncle, aswell you may bid me love my
Maker, and neglect the Creature, which he
Hath bid me love; if man to man joyne not
A love on earth, they love not heaven, nor
Him that dwells above it, such is my duty
A strong Corelative unto
My Vncle why, he's halfe your selfe.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Beleeve me Sir, he has answered you well.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: He has not worthy Sir, but to make voyde
That false construction; here I disclayme
The title of a brother; and by that disclayme
Hast thou lost thy childes part; be thou engag'd
For any debts of his, in prison rot with him;
My goods shall not purchase such
Fruitlesse recompence.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Then th'art a scurvy father, and a filthy brother.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, I, Sir, your tongue cannot defame his reputation

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: But yours can, for all the City reports what
An abominable scould he has got to his wife.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: If ere I know thou keep'st him company,
Ile take my blessing from thee whil'st I live,
And that which after me should blesse thy estate.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: And Ile proclayme thy basenesse to the world;
Ballads I'l make, and make 'm Taverne musick
To sing thy churlish cruelty.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Tut, tut, these are bables.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Each Festivall day I'l come unto thy house,
And I will pisse upon thy threshold.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: You must be out of prison first Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If e'r I live to see thee Sheriffe of London,
I'l gild thy painted postes cum privilegio,
And kick thy Serjeants.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, good Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why, I'l beg for thee, Boy;
I'l breake this leg, and bind it up againe,
To pull out pitty from a stony brest,
Rather than thou shalt want.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I, doe; let him feare up his arme, and scarfe it up
With two yards of rope; counterfeit two villaines;
Beg under a hedge and share your bounty: but come
Not neare my house, not thou in's company, if thoul't obey,
There's punishment, for thee; for thee there's worse;
The losse of all that's mine, with my deare curse.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Churle, Dog, you churlish rascally miser.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, good Vncle, throw not foule language;
This is but heate Sir, and I doubt not but
To coole this rage with my obedience:
But Vncle, you must not then heape on such fuell.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Cuz, I grieve for thee, that thou hast undergone
Thy fathers curse, for love unto thy Vncle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Tut, that bond shall ne'r be cancel'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I pitty that y'faith.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Let pitty then from me turne to your selfe:
Bethinke your selfe Sir, of some course
That might befit your estate, and let me guide it.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha, a course? sfoot I hate: Cuz, canst lend me
40. shillings? Could I but repaire this old decay'd Tenement
Of mine with some new playster; for alas, what
Can a man doe in such a case as this?

sp.speaker: Reb.
sp.l: I, but your course, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Tush, leave that to me, because thou shalt wonder
At it: If you should see me in a scarlet gowne
Within the compasse of a gold chaine, then I
Hope you'l say, that I doe keepe my selfe in
Good compasse: then Sir, if the Cap of Maintenance
Doe march before me, and not a Cap be suffer'd
To be worne in my presence, pray doe not upbraide
Me with my former poverty: I cannot tell, state
And wealth may make a man forget himselfe;
But I beseech you doe not; there are things in my
Head that you dreame not of; dare you try me, Cuz?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Why, forty shillings, Vncle, shall not keepe backe Your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why, gramercy Cuz; now if the dice doe run right,
This 40. shillings may set me up agen: To lay't on my backe,
And so to pawne it, there's ne'r a damb'd Broker
In the world will give me halfe the worth on't:
No, whil'st 'tis in ready cash, that's the surest
Way; 7. is better than 11. a pox take the bones
And they will not favour a man sometimes.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Looke you Vncle, there's 40. shillings for you.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: As many good Angells guard thee, as thou hast given
Me bad ones to seduce me, for these deputy divells
Dam worse than the old ones. Now Cuz, pray listen,
Listen after my transformation; I will henceforth
Turne an Apostate to prodigality; I will eate
Cheese and Onions and buy lordships, and will
Not you thinke this strange?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am glad y'are merry, Vncle; but this is fixt
Betwixt an Vncle and a Nephewes love,
Though my estate be poore, revenewes scant,
Whil'st I have any left, you shall not want.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why gramercy, by this hand Ile make
Thee an Alderman before I dye, doe but
Follow my steps.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Sirra, will the Churchman come I sent you for?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Yes, mistris, he will come: but pray resolve
Me one thing for my long service; What
Businesse have you with the Churchman?
Is it to make your Will, or to get you a new
Husband?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Suppose to make my Will, how then?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Then I would desire you to remember me, Mistris,
I have serv'd you long, and that's the best
Service to a woman: make a good Will if you
Meane to dye, that it may not be said, Though
Most women be long liv'd, yet they all dye
With an ill-will.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: So Sir, suppose it be for marriage.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Why then remember your selfe mistris;
Take heede how you give away the head;
It stands yet upon the shoulders of
Your widdowhood; the loving embracing Ivie
Has yet the upper place in the house;
If you give it to the Holly, take heede,
There's pricks in Holly; or if you feare not
The pricks, take heede of the wands, you
Cannot have the pricks without the wands;
You give away the sword, and must defend
Your selfe with the scabbard; these are pretty
Instructions of a friend; I would be loth to
See you cast downe, and not well taken up.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Well Sir, well, let not all this trouble you;
See, hee's come; Will you be gone?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I will first give him a caveat, to use you
As kindely as he can. If you finde my mistris
Have a minde to this coupling at barly-breake,
Let her not be the last couple to be left in hell.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I would I knew your meaning, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: If she have a minde to a fresh husband, or
So, use her as well as you can; let her enter
Into as easie bands as may be.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir, this is none of my traffique; I sell no husbands.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Then you doe wrong, Sir, for you take mony for 'm:
What woman can have a husband, but you must
Have custome for him? and often the ware proves
Naught too not worth the Impost.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Your mans pregnant, and merry, mistris.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Hee's sawcy Sir. Sirra, you'l be gone.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay, at the second hand you'l have a fee too;
You sell in the Church, and they bring 'm againe
To your Church-yarde, you must have tollage:
Me thinkes if a man dye whether you will or no,
He should be buryed whether you would or no.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Nay now you wade too far, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You'l be gone, Sirra.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Mistris make him your friend, for he knowes what rate
Good husbands are at; if there hath bin a dearth
Of women of late, you may chance picke
Out a good prize; but take heede of a Clerke.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Will you yet Sir, after your needelesse trouble,
Be gone, and bid the maides dresse dinner.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Mistris, 'tis fasting day to day, there's nothing but fish.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Let there be store of that; let bounty furnish the
Table, and charity shall be the voyder.
What fish is there, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Marry there is Sammon, Pike, and fresh Cod,
Soles, Maides, and Playce.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Bid 'm haste to dresse 'm then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay mistris, I'le helpe 'm too; the maides shall first
Dresse the Pike, and the Cod, and then I'le dresse
The maides in the place you wot on.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You sent for me, Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Sir, I did, and to this end:
I have some scruples in my conscience;
Some doubtfull problemes which I cannot answer
Nor reconcile; I'de have you make them plaine.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: This is my duty; pray speake your minde.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: And as I speak, I must remember heaven
That gave those blessings which I must relate:
Sir, you now behold a wondrous woman;
You onely wonder at the Epithete;
I can approve it good; Ghesse at mine age.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: At the halfe way 'twixt thirty and forty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: 'Twas not much amisse; yet nearest to the last;
How thinke you then; Is not this a wonder,
That a woman lives full seven and thirty yeares,
Mayde to a wife, and wife unto a widdow,
Now widdowed, and mine owne, yet all this while
From the extremest verge of my remembrance,
Even from my weaning houre unto this minute,
Did never taste what was calamity;
I know not yet what griefe is, yet have sought
A hundred wayes for its acquaintance; with mee
Prosperity hath kept so close a watch,
That even those things that I have meant
A crosse, have that way turn'd a blessing;
Is it not strange?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Vnparaleld; this gift is singular,
And to you alone belonging; you are the Moone,
For there's but one, all women else are stars,
For there are none of like condition:
Full oft, and many have I heard complaine
Of discontents, thwarts, and adversities;
But a second to your selfe, I never knew
To groane under the superflux of blessings,
To have ever bin a lien unto sorrow;
No trip of fate? Sure it is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I, Sir, tis wonderfull; but is it well?
For it is now my chiefe affliction.
I have heard you say, that the child of heaven
Shall suffer many tribulations;
Nay, Kings and Princes share them with their subjects;
Then I that know not any chastisement
How may I know my part of childhood?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis a good doubt; but make it not extreme,
'Tis some affliction, that you are afflicted
For want of affliction: Cherish that;
Yet wrest it not to misconstruction;
For all your blessings are free gifts from heaeven
Health, wealth, and peace; nor can they turn to
Curses, but by abuse. Pray let me question you:
You lost a husband, was it no griefe to you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It was; but very small; no sooner I
Had given it entertainement as a sorrow,
But straite it turn'd unto my treble joy;
A comfortable revelation prompts me then,
That husband whom in life I held so deare,
Had chang'd a frailty to unchanging joyes;
Me thought I saw him stellified in heaven,
And singing Hallelujahs 'mongst a quire
Of white Sainted soules: then againe it spake,
And said; It was a sinne for me to grieve
At his best good, that I esteemed best:
And thus this slender shadow of a griefe
Vanish't againe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: All this was happy; nor can you wrest it
From a heavenly blessing. Doe not appoint
The rod: leave still the stroake unto the
Magistrate; the time is not past, but
You may feele enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: One tast more I had, although but little,
Yet I would aggravate to make the most
On't: thus 'twas; The other day, it was my hap
In crossing of the Thames,
To drop that wedlocke Ring from off my finger,
That once conjoyn'd me and my dead husband;
It sunke, I pris'd it deare; the dearer, 'cause it kept
Still in mine eye the memory of my losse;
Yet I griev'd the losse, and did joy withall
That I had found a griefe; and this is all
The sorrow I can boast of.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: This is but small.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay sure I am of this opinion,
That had I suffer'd a draught to be made for it,
The bottome would have sent it up againe,
I am so wondrouslie fortunate.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You would not suffer it?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Not for my whole estate.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O mistris, where are you? I thinke you are the fortunat'st Woman, that ever breath'd of two shoes: the thiefe is Found.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The thiefe; what thiefe? I never was so happy To be robb'd.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Bring him away Iug; nay, you shall see the strangest
Piece of felony discover'd that ever you saw,
Or your great grandmothers Grandam before, or after,
A pirate, a water thiefe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Bring him away Iug; yet the villaine would not Confesse a word till it was found about him.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I thinke the fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Did you not lose your wedding Ring the other day?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Yes Sir, but I was not robb'd of it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: No; well, thanke him that brings it
Home then; and will aske nothing for his paines.
You see this Sammon?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Yes, what of it?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: It cost but six pence: but had the Fisher knowne
The worth of it, 'twould have cost you forty shillings.
Is not this your Ring?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Your maid Ioane examining this Sammon, that shee
Bought in the Market, found that he had swallowed
This Gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: How am I vext with blessings? how thinke you
Sir, is not this above wonder?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I am amaz'd at it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: First that this fish should snatch it as a baite;
Then that my servant needes must buy that fish
Amongst such infinites of fish and buyers:
What fate is mine that runnes all by it selfe
In unhappy happinesse? My conscience dreads it:
Would thou hadst not swallowed it, nor thou not bought it.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Alas, blame not the poore fish, mistris, hee being a flegmatique
sp.l: Creature, tooke Gold for Restorative. He tooke it faire,
And he that gets Gold, let him eate Gold.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nothing can hinder fate.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Seeke not to crosse it then.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: About your businesse, you have not pleas'd me in this.

sp.speaker: Ioane.
sp.l: By my maydenhead if I had thought you would
Have tane it no kindlier, you should ne'r
Have bin vext with sight on't; the garbidge should
Have bin the Cookes fees at this time.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Now doe I see the old proverbe come to passe;
Give a woman lucke, and cast her into th'sea:
There's many a man would wish his wife good
Lucke, on that condition he might throw her
Away so. But mistris, there's one within would
Speake with you, that vexeth as fast against
Crosses, as you doe against good lucke.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I know her sure then, 'tis my gossip Foster:
Request her in; here's good company, tell her.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Ile tell her so for my owne credits sake.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You shall now see an absolute contrary:
Would I had chang'd bosomes with her for a time,
'T would make me better rellish happinesse.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O friend and gossip, where are you? I am
O're loaden with my griefes, and but in your bosome
I know not where to ease me.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: I had rather helpe you to a close, stoole,
And't please you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Ne'r had woman more sinister fate;
All ominous stars were in conjunction
Even at my birth, and doe still attend me.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: This is a perfect contrary indeede.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: What ayles you Woman?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Vnlesse seven witches had set spels about me,
I could not be so crost, never at quiet
Never happy houre, not a minutes content.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You hurt your selfe most with impatience.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, I Physitions minister with ease,
Although the patient do receive in paine;
Would I could think but of one joyfull houre.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You have had two husbands to my knowledge;
And if you had not one joyfull houre betweene
Both, I would you were hang'd i'faith.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Full fourteene yeeres I liv'd a weary mayde,
Thinking no joy till I had got a husband.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That was a tedious time indeede.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I had one lov'd me well, and then ere long
I grew into my longing peevishnesse.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: There was some pleasure ere you came to that.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Then all the kindenesse that he would apply,
Nothing could please; soone after it he died.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: That could be but little griefe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Then worldly care did so o'reload my weakenesse,
That I must have a second stay; I chose againe,
And there begins my griefes to multiply.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: It cannot be, friend; your husband's kinde.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: A man of faire condition, well reputed.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: But it may be he has not that should please her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Peace Sirra: how can your sorrowes encrease from him?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: How can they but o'rewhelme me? he keepes a Son
That makes my state his prodigality;
To him a brother, one of the Citty scandals;
The tone the hand, the tother is the maw;
And betweene both my goods are swallowed up;
The full quantity that I brought amongst'm
Is now consum'd to halfe.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: The fire of your spleene wasts it;
Good sooth Gossip, I could laugh at thee, and onely grieve
I have not some cause of sorrow with thee:
Prithee be temperate, and suffer.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Tis good counsell mistris, receive it so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Canst thou devise to lay them halfe on me,
And Ile beare'm willingly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Would I could, that I might laugh another while:
But you are wise to heede at others harmes;
You'l keepe you happy in your widdowhood.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Not I in good faith, were I sure marriage
Would make me unhappy.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Try, try, you shall not neede to wish;
You'l sing another song, and beare a part
In my griefes descant, when y'are vext at heart:
Your second choyse will differ from the first:
So oft as widdowes marry they are accurst.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I, curst widdowes are; but if they had all stiffe husbands
To tame'm, they'd be quiet enough.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You'l be gone Sir, and see dinner ready.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I care not if I doe mistris, now my stomack's ready;
Yet Ile stay a little and be but to vex you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: When goe you, Sirra?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I will not goe yet.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, thou makest me laugh at thee; prethee stay,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay then Ile goe to vex you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: You have a light heart Gossip.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: So should you Woman, would you be ruld by me:
Come, we'l dine together, after walke abroad
Vnto my suburbe garden, where if thou'lt heare,
I le read my heart to thee, and thou from thence
Shalt learne to vex thy cares with patience.

div.head: Actus Secundus.
div.stage: Enter Host Boxall, Stephen, Iacke, Dicke, Hugh.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: WElcome still my merchants of bona Speranza;
sp.p: What's your trafficke Bulleyes? What ware deale you in?
sp.l: Cards, Dice, Bowles, or Pigeon-holes; sort'm
Your selves; either Passage, Novum, or Mumchance?
Say my brave Bursmen, what's your recreation?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Dice mine Host: Is there no other roome empty?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Not a hole unstopt in my house, but this my Thrifts.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Miscall us not for our money, good mine Host, we are
None of your thrifts; we have scap'd that scandall long agoe.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Yes, his thrifts we are Iacke, though not our owne.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Tush, you are young men, 'tis too soone to thrive yet:
He that gathers young, spends when hee's old:
'Tis better to begin ill, and end well, than to
Begin well and end ill: Miserable fathers have
For the most part unthrifty sons; leave not
Too much for your heires, Boyes.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Hee sayes well i'faith; Why should a man trust
To executors.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: As good trust to hangmen as to executors:
Who's in the bowling Alley mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Honest traders, thrifty lads, they are rubbing on't;
Towardly Boyes, every one strives to lye nearest the Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Give's a bayle of Dice.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Here my brave Wags.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: We feare no Counters now mine Host, so
Long as we have your bayle so ready.
Come, trip.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Vp with's heeles.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Downe with them.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Now the dice are mine; set me now a faire
Boord; a faire passage sweet bones. Boreas.

div.stage: A noyse below in the bowling Alley, betting, rubbing and wrangling.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How now my fine Trundletayles;
My wodden Cosmographers:
My bowling Alley in an uprore?
Is Orlando up in armes? I must be stickler;
I am Constable, Iustice, and Beadle in mine
Owne house, I accuse, sentence, and punish:
Have amongst you; looke to my box Boyes;
He that breakes the peace, I breake his pate
For recompence; looke to my box, I say.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.p: A pox o'your box, I shall ne'r be so happy to Reward it better; set me faire; aloft now.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Out.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: What wast?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: Two Trayes, and an Ace.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Seven still, pox on't; that number of the
Deadly sinnes haunts me damnably; Come Sir, throw.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Prethee invoke not so, all sinkes too fast already.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: It will be found againe in mine hosts box.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: In still, two theeves and choose thy fellow.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Take the Miller.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Have at them i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: For a thiefe Ile warrant you, who'l you have next.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Two Quaters and a Tray.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I hope we shall have good cheere, when two
Caters, and a Tray goe toth' market.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: So all's whist; they play upon the still pipes now,
The Bull-beggar comes when I shew my head,
Silence is a vertue, and I have made'm vertuous,
Let'm play still till they be penny lesse; pawne
Till they be naked, so they be quiet, welcome,
And welcome.
How now, how now, my roaring Tamberlaine, take
Heede the Soldan comes; And 'twere not for proffit,
Who would live amongst such Beares? why Vrsa
Major I say, what in Capite Draconis? is there
No hope to reclayme you, shall I never live in quiet
For you?

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.p: Good mine Host still'm: civill Gamesters cannot play for'm.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I come amongst you, you maledictious slaves; I'l
Vtter you all; some I'l take ready money for, and lay
Vp the rest in the stocks: looke to my box, I say.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Your box is like your belly mine Host, it
Drawes all; now for a suite of apparell.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: At whose suit I pray? y'are out againe with the threes.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Foote, I thinke my father threw three when I was
Begotten; pox on't, I know now why I am so
Haunted with threes.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: Why, I prethee?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I met the third part of a knave as I came.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: The third part of a knave, s'foote what thing's that?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Why a Serjants Yeoman, man; the supervisor himselfe
Is but a whole one, and he shares but a groate in the
Shilling with him.

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: That's but the third part indeed: but goes he no further.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: No, he rests there.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Come, let's give o're.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I thanke you Sir, and so much a looser? there's but
The wast-band of my suite left: now sweete bones.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Twelve at all.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Soft, this dye is false.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: False? you doe him wrong Sir, hee's true to his Master.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Fullum:

sp.speaker: Dick.
sp.l: I'le be hang'd then: where's Putney then I pray you

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: 'Tis false, and I'le have my money againe.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: You shall have cold Iron with your silver then.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: I, have at you Sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: I thinke hee's here, Sir.

div.stage: Young Foster assists his Uncle and the Host, and beat se them off; Enter the Bowlers and steale away their Cloakes.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am sure hee's now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hugh.
sp.l: Hold, hold, and you be Gentlemen hold.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Get you gone Varlets, or there's hold to be taken.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Nay sweete Sir, no bloodshed in my house; I am lord Of misrule, pray you put up, Sir.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.l: S'foote mine Host, where are our cloakes?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Why, this is quarrelling; Make after in time:
Some of your owne Crew, to try the weight has
Lifted them; looke out I say.

sp.speaker: Iack.
sp.l: There will ever be theeves in a dicing house
Till thou bee'st hang'd I'l warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Mine Host, my Cloake was lin'd through with
Oringe tawney velvet.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How, your cloake? I ne'r knew thee worth one.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Y'are a company of Conycatching rascals;
Is this a suite to walke without a Cloake in?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Vncle, is this the reformation that you promis'd mee?

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Cuz, shall I tell thee the truth; I had diminish't
But six pence of the forty shillings by chance meeting with a
Friend, I went to a taylor, bargain'd for a suite, it
Came to full forty, I tender'd my xxxix and a halfe,
And doe you thinke the scabby-wristed rascall would
Trust me for six pence.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your credit is the better, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Pox on him, if the taylor had bin a man, I had
Had a faire suite on my backe, so venturing for
The tother Tester

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You lost the whole Bed-stead.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: But after this day, I protest Cuz, you shall never
See me handle those bones againe; this day I
Breake up schoole: if ever you call me unthrift after
This day, you doe me wrong.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I should be glad to wrong you so, Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: And what sayes your father yet, Cuz?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'le tell you that in your eare.

div.stage: Enter Mistris Foster, Widdow and Clowne.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Nay, I pray you friend beare me company a little
This way, for into this dicing house I saw my good
Son in law enter, and 'tis ods but he meetes his
Vncle here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You cannot tire me gossip in your company, 'tis the best
Affliction I have to see you impatient.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, I, you may make mirth of my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: We have hunted well, mistris; doe you not see
The hare's in sight?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Did not I tell you so; I, I, there's good counsell
Betweene you, the tone would goe afoote to hell,
The other the horseway.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Mother, I am sorry you have trod this path.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Mother? hang thee wretch, I bore thee not, but
Many afflictions I have borne for thee; wert thou
Mine owne, I'd see thee stretcht a handfull, and
Put thee a Coffin into the Cart, ere thou shouldst vex
Me thus.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Were I your owne, you could not use me worse than you doe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'l make thy father turne thee out for ever, or else
I'l make him wish him in his grave; You'l witnesse
With me Gossip where I have found him.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.l: Nay, I'l be sworne upon a booke of Callico for that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: It shal not neede, I'l not deny that I was with my Vncle.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: And that shall disinherit thee, if thy father
Be an honest man; thou hadst bin better to have
Bin borne a viper, and eate thy way through thy
Mothers wombe into the world, than to tempt my
Displeasure.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou lyest Zantippe; it had bin better thou hadst
Bin prest to death under two Irish Rugs, than to
Ride honest Socrates thy husband thus, and abuse his
Honest childe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Out Raggamuffin, dost thou talke? I shall see thee
In Ludgate againe shortly.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Thou lyest agen, 'twilbe at More-gate, Beldam, where I shall see thee in the Ditch dancing in a Cucking-stoole.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'l see thee hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou lyest againe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay Sir, you doe wrong to give a woman so many lies,
Shee had rather have had twice so many standings, than
One lye.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I'l lye with him I'l warrant him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You'l be a whore then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Little lesse I promise you, if you lye with him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If you complaine upon mine honest Cuz,
And that his father be offended with him,
The next time I meete thee, though it be i'th' streete,
The dance i'the durt upon thy velvet Cap;
Nay worse, Plestaine thy Ruffe; nay worse than that,
I'l doe thus:

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O my hart Gossip, do you see this? Was ever
Woman thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Me thinkes 'tis good sport y'faith.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, I am well recompenc'd to complaine to you,
Had you such a kindred.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I would rejoyce in't Gossip.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Do so; choose here then; Oh my hart! But I'l doe
Your errand; Oh that my Nayles were not par'd! But I'l doe
Your errand; Will you goe Gossip?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: No I'l stay awhile and tell 'm out with patience.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I cannot hold a joynt still; Dost wispe me, thou
tatterdemallion; I'l doe your errands, if I have a
Husband; Oh that I could spit Wild fire!
My heart, Oh my heart! If it does not goe pantle,
Pantle, pantle in my belly, I am no honest woman:
But I'l doe your errands.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Kinde Gentlewoman, you have some patience.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I have too much Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: You may doe a good office, and make your selfe a Peacefull moderator betwixt me and my angry
Father, whom his wife hath mou'd to spleene Against me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Sir, I doe not disallow the kindenesse your
Consanguinity renders, I would not teach
You otherwise; I'd speake with your Vncle, Sir,
If you'l give me leave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You may talke with me Sir, in the meane time.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: With me would you talke, Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Yes Sir, with you; you are a brave Vnthrift.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Not very brave neither; yet I make a shift

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: When you have a cleane shirt.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l be no Pupill to a woman; leave your discipline.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Nay, pray you heare me Sir, I cannot chide.
I'l but give you good counsell; 'tis not a good
Course that you run.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet I must run to'th end of it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I would teach you a better, if you'd stay where you are.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I would stay where I am, if I had any money.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: In the dycing house?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I thinke so too, I have play'd at Passage all
This while, now I'd go to Hazard.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Dost thou want Money? Thou art worthy to be tatter'd
Hast thou no wit now thy Money's gone?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis all the portion I have;
I have nothing to maintaine me but my wit;
My Money is too little I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I cannot beleeve thy wit's more than thy Money,
A fellow so well limb'd, so able to doe good service,
And want.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Why Mistris, my shoulders were not made for a Frock
And a Basket, nor a Coale-sacke neither, no nor
My hands to turne a trencher at a tables side.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I like that resolution well; but how comes it
Then, that thy wit leaves thy body unfurnisht?
Thou art very poore?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The fortune of the Dice you see.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: They are the onely wizards, I confesse,
The onely fortune-tellers; but he that goes to
Seeke his fortune from them, must never hope
To have a good destiny allotted him: yet it is
Not the course that I dislike in thee, but that
Thou canst not supply that course, and out-
Crosse them that crosse thee; Were I as thou art

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You'd be as beggarly as I am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I'l be hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Nay, you must be well hang'd e'r you can be as I am.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: So Sir, I conceite you; were I as well hang'd then
As you could imagine, I would tell some rich widow
Such a tale in her eare.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? Some rich widdow? By this pennilesse pocket,
I thinke 'twere not the worst way.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I'd be asham'd to take such a fruitlesse oath:
I say, seeke me out some rich widow; promise
Her faire; shee's apt to believe a young man;
Marry her, and let her estate fly; no matter,
'Tis charity; Twenty to one some rich Miser rak'd
it together; this is none of Hercules labours.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? let me recount these articles: Seeke her out;
Promise her faire; Marry her; Let her estate fly:
But where should I finde her?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: The easyest of all: Why man, they are more common
Than Taverne Bushes; two Fayres might be
Furnish'd every weeke in London with 'm, though no
Forrainers came in, if the Charter were granted once:
Nay, 'tis thought, if the Horse-market be remov'd, that
Smithfield shall be so imploy'd, and then I'l
Warrant you 'twill be as well furnishd with widowes as
Twas with Sowes, Cowes, and old trotting Iades before.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: S'foote, if it were, I would be a Chapman; I'd see for
My pleasure, and buy for my love, for money I have none.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Thou shalt not stay the Market; if thoul't be rul'd,
I'l finde thee out a widdow, and helpe in some of
The rest too; if thou'lt but promise me the last, but
To let her estate fly: for shee's one I loue not, and
I'd be glad to see that revenge on her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Spend her estate, wer't five Aldermens; I'l put you
In security for that, sfoote all my neighbours shall be bound
For me, nay, my kinde Sister in law shall passe her word
For that.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Onely this I'l enjoyne you, to be matrimonially honest
To her for your owne healthes sake: all other injuries
Shall be blessings to her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l blesse her then; I ever drunke so much,
That I was never great feeder; give me drinke,
And my pleasure, and a little flesh serves my turne.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I'l shew thee the party; What sayest thou to my self?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Your selfe, Gentlewoman, I would it were no worse;
I have heard you reputed a rich widdow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I have a lease of thousands at least, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l let out your leases for you, if you'l allow me
The power I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: That's my hope Sir; but you must be honest withall.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l be honest with some; if I can he honest with all,
I will too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Give me thy hand; goe home with me, I'l give
The better clothes; and as I like thee then, we'l
Goe further, we may chance make a blinde
Bargaine of it.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I can make no blind bargaine, unlesse I be
In your bed, Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: No, I bar that Sir, lets begin honestly, how E'r
we end; marry for the waste of my estate
Spare it not; doe thy worst.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l doe bad enough, feare it not.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Come, will you walk, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No Widow, I'l stand to no hazard of blinde
Bargaines; either promise me marriage, and give
Me earnest in a handfast, or I'l not budge
A foote.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: No Sir, are you growne so stout already?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l grow stouter when I am marryed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I hope thou'lt vex me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l give you cause I'l warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I shall rayle, and curse thee I hope; yet I'd
Not have thee give over neither; for I would
Be vext; Here's my hand, I am thine, thou art mine,
I'l have thee withall faults.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You shall have one with some, and you have mee,

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: Here's witnesse, come hither Sir.
Cozin, I must call you shortly; and you
Sirra, be witnesse to this match; here's Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I joy at mine Vncles happinesse, Widdow.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I doe forbid the Banes: Alas poore Shagragge,
My Mistris does but gull him; you may
Imagine it to be Twelfe-day at night, and the
Beane found in the corner of your Cake, but
Tis not worth a fetch I'l assure you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You'l let me dispose of my selfe, I hope.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You love to be merry Mistris; Come, come,
Give him foure Farthings, and let him goe.
He'l pray for his good Dame, and be drunke;
Why, if your blood does itch that way, we'l
Stand together; how thinke you? I thinke here
is the sweeter bit, you see this Nap, and you
See this Lowse, you may cracke o' your choyse,
If you choose here.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: You have put me to my choyse then; see, here I choose?
This is my Husband: Thus I begin the Contract.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis seal'd, I am thine; now Cuz feare no blacke
Stormes; if thy father thunder, come to me for shelter.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: His word is now a deede, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I thanke you both. Vncle, what my joy conceives,
I cannot utter yet.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I will make blacke Munday of this: e'r I suffer
This disgrace, the kennell shall run with blood and rags,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, I am your apposite.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I have nothing to say to you, Sir; I ayme at your Vncle

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He has no weapon.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: That's all one, I'l take him as I finde him:

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.l: I have taken him so before you, Sir; Will you be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou shalt take me so too Hodge, for I'l be thy fellow,
Though thy Mistrisses Husband. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I'l make you seeke your fingers among the Dogs,
If you come to me; my Fellow? You lowsie
Companion; I scorne thee. S'foote, is't come to this?
Have I stood all this while to my Mistris, an honest,
Hansome, plaine-dealing, serving-Creature; and she to
Marry a Worson Tittere Tu Tattere with never a good rag
About him? Stand thou to me, and be my friend; and since
My Mistris has forsaken me:

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Twas well you came in good time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Why man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I was going the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: But tell me one thing, I apprehend not; Why didst
Lay thy Cap upon the swords point?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Do'st not thou know the reason of that? why, 'twas
To save my belly: dost thou thinke I am so mad to
Cast my selfe away for e'r a woman of'm all,
I'l see 'm hang'd first.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Come Roger, will you goe?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Well, since there is no remedy, Oh teares bee you my friend!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nay, prethee Roger doe not cry.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I cannot choose; nay I will steepe
Mine eyes in crying teares, and crying weepe.

div.head: Actus Tertius.
div.stage: Enter Alderman Bruine, Sir Godfry Speedwell, Innocent Lambskin, and Mistris Iane.

sp.speaker: Bruine.
sp.l: GEntlemen, y'are welcome; that once well pronounc'd
Has a thousand Ecchoes; Let it suffice, I have spoke
It to the full: here's your affaires, here's your merchandize,
This is your prise, if you can mix your names and gentle
Bloods with the poore Daughter of a Cittizen.
I make the passage free, to greete and court,
Traffique the mart of love, clap hands and strike
The bargaine through, (she pleas'd) and I shall like.

sp.speaker: God. Sp.
sp.l: 'Tis good ware believe me, Sir, I know that by mine
Owne experience; for I have handled the like
Many times in my first wives dayes, I, by Knighthood,
Sometimes before I was marryed too; therefore I
Know't by mine owne experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Well Sir, I know by observation, as much as you doe
By experience; for I have knowne many Gentlemen
Have taken up such ware as this is, but it has lyen
On their hands as long as they liv'd; this I
Have seene by observation.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I am like to have a couple of faire Chapmen:
If they were at my owne dispose, I would
Willingly rifle them both at twelve pence a share; they
Would be good foode for a new plantation; the
Tone might mend his experience; and the other his
Observation very much.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir, let me advise you: I see you want experience,
Meddle no further in this case, 'twilbe the
More credit for your observation; for I finde by my
Experience, you are but shallow.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: But shallow Sir? Your experience is a little wide;
You shall finde I wilbe as deepe in this case as
Your selfe; my observation has bin, where your
Experience must waite at doore; yet I will
Give you the fore Horse place, and I wilbe in the
Fill's, because you are the elder Tree, and I the
Young Plant; put on your experience, and I will
Observe.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sweete Virgin, to be prolix and tedious, fits no
Experience; short words and large deedes are
Best pleasing to women.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: So, Sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: My name is Speedwell, by my fathers Coppy.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Then you never serv'd for't it seemes.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Yes, sweete Feminine, I have serv'd for it too:
For I have found my nativity suited to my name,
As my name is Speedwel, so have I sped
Well in divers actions.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: It must needes be a faire and comely suit then.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You observe very well, sweete Virgine; for his
Nativity is his Dublet, which is the upper part
Of his suite; and his name is in's breeches, for
That part which is his name, he defiles many times.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Your observation is corrupt, Sir; Let me shew mine
Owne Tale; I say, sweete Beauty, my name is
Speedewell, my God-father by his bounty being an
Old Soldiour, and having serv'd in the wars as far as
Bulloyne, therefore cal'd my name Godfry; a
Title of large renowne; my wealth and wit has
Added to those, the paraphrase of Knighthood;
So that my name in the full longitude is cal'd
Sir Godfry Speedwell, a name of good experience.

sp.speaker: Ian.
sp.l: If every quality you have be as large in relation as
Your name Sir, I should imagine the best of them, rather
Than heare them reported.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: You say well, sweet Modesty, a good imagination is good,
sp.l: And shewes your good experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Nay, if names can do any good, I beseech you observe
Mine; My name is Lambskin, a thing both hot and harmelesse.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: On Sir, I would not interrupt you, because you Should be briefe.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: My Godfather seeing in my face some notes of disposition,
sp.l: In my Cradle did give me the title of Innocent, which I
Have practis'd all my life time; and since my fathers
Decease, my wealth has purchast me in the vanguard
Of my name, the paraphrase of gentility; So that
I am cald Master Innocent Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: In good time; and what Trade was your father, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: My father was of an Occupation before he was a
Tradesman; for, as I have observ'd in my fathers
And mothers report, they set up together in
Their youth; my father was a Starch-maker, and my
Mother a Laundresse; so being partners, they did
Occupy long together before they were marryed;
Then was I borne.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: What, before your father was marryed?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Truly a little after, I was the first fruits, as they say;
Then did my father change his Copy, and set up
A Brewhouse.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I then came your wealth in, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Your observation's good; I have carryed the Tallyes
At my girdle seven yeares together with much
Delight and observation; for I did ever love to
Deale honestly in the Nick.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: A very innocent resolution.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Your experience may see his course education; but to
The purpose, sweet Female; I doe love that
Face of yours.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Sir, if you love nothing but my face, I cannot sell it
From the rest.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You may see his slender observation; sweet Virgin,
I doe love your lower parts better than your face.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sir you doe interrupt, and thwart my love.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I Sir, I am your Rivall; and I will thwart your love.
For your love licks at the face, and my love
Shall be Arsy-Versy to yours.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I would desire no better wooing of so bad suitors.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Mistake me not kinde Heart.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: He cals you Tooth drawer by way of experience.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: In loving your face, I love all the rest of your body
As you shall finde by experience.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Well Sir, you love me then?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Let your experience make a tryall.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: No Sir, I'l beleeve you rather, and I thanke you for't.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I love you too, faire Maide, double and treble,
If it please you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I thanke you too Sir; I am so much beholding
To you both; I am affraid I shall never requite it.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Requite one, sweete Chastity, and let it be
Sir Godfry, with the correspondencie of your
Love to him; I will maintaine you like a Lady,
And it is brave, as I know by experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I will maintaine you like a Gentlewoman: And
That may be better maintenance than a Ladies,
As I have found by observation.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: How dare you maintaine that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I dare maintaine it with my purse, Sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: I dare crosse it with my sword Sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: If you dare crosse my purse with your sword Sir,
I'l lay an action of suspition of felony to you;
That's flat, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Nay, pray you Gentlemen doe not quarrell,
Till you know for what.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Oh, no quarrelling, I beseech you Gentlemen!
The reputation of my house is soyld, if any
Vncivill noyse arise in't.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Let him but shake his blade at me, and I'l
Throw downe my purse, and cry a rape; I
Scorne to kill him, but I'l hang his knighthood,
I warrant him, if he offer assault and battry on
My purse.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir, put up your sword.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: You have confinde him prisoner forever,
I hope your experience sees hee's a harmelesse thing.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sir, heres young Master Foster requests
To speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Does he? Prethee request him. Gentlemen,
Please you taste the sweetenesse of my Garden
A while, and let my daughter beare you company.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Where she is leader, there will be followers.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: You send me to the Gallyes, Sir; pray you redeeme
Me as soone as you can; these are pretty
Things for mirth, but not for serious uses.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Prethee be merry with them then a while,
If but for curtesie; thou hast wit enough;
But take heede they quarrell not.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Nay I dare take in hand to part'm without
Any danger; but I beseech you let me not
Be too long a prisoner. Will you walke Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: If it please you to place one of us for your conduct,
Otherwise this old Coxcombe and I shall quarrell.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Sir Godfry, you are the eldest; pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: With all my heart, sweet Virgin; Ah, ha; this place
Promises well in the eyes of experience; Master
Innocent, come you behinde.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Right Sir; but I put the Gentlewoman before, and that
Is the thing I desire
And there your experience halts a little.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: When I looke backe, Sir, I see your nose behinde.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Then when I looke backe, your nose stands here.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, follow experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: And let observation follow you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So, now request you Master Foster in, George; but hark;
Does that newes hold his owne still, that our ships
Are so neare returne, as laden on the Downes
With such a wealthy fraughtage.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and the next Tide purpose to put into the River:
Master Foster, your partner, hath now receiv'd more
Such intelligence, with most of the particulars
Of your merchandize, your venture is return'd
With trebble blessing.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Let him be ever blest that sent. George now call
In the young man; and hearke yee, George, from him
Run to my Partner, and request him to me, this
Newes I'm sure makes him a joyfull Merchant;
For my owne part, I'l not forget my vow,
This free addition heaven hath lent my state,
As freely backe to heaven I'l dedicate.
I marry Sir, would this were a third Sutor
To my daughter Iane, I should better
Like him than all that's come yet. Now master Foster,
Are your father and your selfe yet reconcil'd?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, 'twas my businesse in your courteous tongue
To put the arbitration, I have againe
(Discover'd by my mother) reliev'd my poore Vncle,
Whose anger now so great is multiplyed,
I dare not venter in the eye of either,
Till your perswasions with faire excuse
Have made my satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mother a pearle, Sir, 'tis a shrewd taske;
Yet I'l doe my best; your father hath so good newes,
That I hope't will be a faire motive too't;
But womens tongues are dangerous stumbling blocks
To lye in the way of peace. Now George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Master Foster's comming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I beseech you Sir, let not me see him, till you
Have confer'd with him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well, well, e'r your returne to Master Foster, call my
Daughter forth of the garden.
And how does your Vncle, Master Foster?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, so well, I'd be loth to anticipate the
Same that shortly will o're-spread the city of his good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Why I commend thee still,
He wants no good from thee, no not in report:
'Tis well done Sir, and you shew duty in't.
Now daughter, Where are your lusty Suitors?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I was glad of my release, Sir: Suitors call you'm,
I'd keepe dish water continually boyling, but I'd
Seeth such Suitors; I have had much adoe to
Keepe'm from bloodshed; I have seene for all
The world, a couple of cowardly Curs quarrell
In that fashion, as t'one turnes his head, the
Other snaps behind; and as he turnes, his
Mouth recoyles againe: but I thanke my paines
For't, I have leagu'd with'm for a weeke without
Any farther entercourse.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well daughter, well; say a third trouble come;
Say in the person of young Master Foster here
Came a third Suitor: how then?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Three's the womans totall Arithmeticke in
Deede, I would learne to number no farther,
If there was a good account made of that.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I can instruct you so far, sweet Beauty.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Take heede, Sir; I have had ill handsell to day;
Perhaps 'tis not the fortunate season, you were
Best adjourne your journey to some happier time.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: There shall no Augurisme fright my plaine
Dealing: Sweete, I feare no houres.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: You'l not betray me with love-powder

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Nor with Gun-powder neither ifaith; yet I'l
Make you yeeld if I can.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Goe, get you together; your father will be comming;
Leave me with your suite to him, ply this your selfe;
And Iane, use him kindly, he shall be his
Fathers heire I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Never the more for that, Father; If I use him
Kindely, it shalbe for something I like in him.
Selfe, and not for any good he borrowes of his father,
But come Sir, will you walke into the Garden; for
That's the field I have best fortune to overcome
My Suitors in.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I feare not that fate neither, but if I walke
Into your Garden, I shall be tasting your sweetes.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Taste sweetely and welcome Sir; for there growes
Honesty, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I shall be plucking at your honesty.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: By my honesty but you shall not Sir: I'l hold
You a hand full of Penny-royall of that y'faith,
If you touch my honesty there, I'l make you eate
Sorrill to your supper, though I eate Sullenwood my selfe:
No Sir, gather first Time and Sage, and such wholsome
Hearbes; and Honesty and Hearts-ease will ripen
The whil'st.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You have faire Roses, have you not?

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Yes Sir, Roses; but no Gillyflowers.

div.stage: Enter Master Foster and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Goe, goe, and rest on Uenus Violets; shew her
A dozin of Batchelors Button Boy; Here comes
His father. Now my kind Partner, have we
Good newes?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, in a word, take it; Your full lading and venture
Is return'd at sixty fold encrease.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Heaven take the glory; A wondrous blessing;
Oh keepe us strong against these flowing Tides!
Man is too weak to bound himselfe below,
When such high waves doe mount him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O Sir, care and ambition seldome meete,
Let us be thrifty; Titles will faster come,
Than we shall wish to have them.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Faith I desire none.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why Sir, if so you please, I'l ease your cares;
Shall I like a full adventurer now bid you
A certaine ready sum for your halfe traffique.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I, and I'd make you gainer by it too;
For then would I lay by my trouble, and begin
A worke which I have promis'd unto heaven,
A house, a Domus Dei shall be rays'd,
Which shall to Doomesday be establish'd for succour to
The poore; for in all Ages there must be such.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I bid your venture at a venter.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Pray you doe Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Twenty thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, then you under-rate your owne value much;
Will you make it thirty?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Shall I meete you halfe way?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: I meete you there Sir; for five and twenty thousand Pounds the full ventures yours.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: If you like my payment, 'tis the one halfe in ready Cash, the other seal'd for six Monethes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis Merchant like and faire; George, you
Observe this? Let the contents be drawne.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: They shall Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Your hazard is now all past, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I rejoyce at it, Sir, and shall not grudge your gaines,
Though multiplyed to thousands.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: Beleeve me Sir, I account my selfe a large Gainer by you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Much good may it be to you, Sir; but one
Thing at this advantage of my love to you
Let me entreate.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What is it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Faith my old suite, to reconcile those breaches
Twist your kinde son and you; Let not the love
He shewes unto his Vncle, be any more a bar
To sunder your blessings and his duty.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I would you had enjoyn'd me some great labour
Far your owne loves sake, but to that my
View stands fixt against; I'm deafe,
Obdurat to either of them.

sp.speaker: M Fost.
sp.l: Nay, Sir, if you knew all, you would not waste your
Words in so vaine expence: since his last
Reformation, he has flowne out againe,
And in my sight relieved his Vncle in the
Dicing house; for which, either he shalbe no
Father to him, or no husband to me.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Well Sir, go call my Daughter forth of the
Garden, and bid her bring her Friend along
With her, troth Sir, I must not leave you thus;
I must needes make him your son againe.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, I have no such thing a kin to me.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Looke you Sir, know you this duty?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Not I Sir: hee's a stranger to me: Save your
Knee, I have no blessing for you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Goe, goe to your Vncle Sir; you know where to
Finde him, hee's at his old haunt, he wants
More money by this time; but I thinke the
Conduite pipe is stopt from whence it ran.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Did he not say, hee'd beg for you, you'd best
Make use of's bounty.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, if your daughter cast any eye of favour upon
This Vnthrift restraint, hee's a beggar: Mistris
Iane, take heede what you doe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, I, be wise Mistris Iane; doe not you trust
To spleene and time worne to pitty, you'l
Not finde it so; therefore good Gentlewoman
Take heede.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Nay then you are too impenitrable.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Sir, your money shall be ready, and your bills;
Other businesse I have none: For thee,
Beg, hang, dye like a slave;
Such blessings ever thou from me shalt have.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Well Sir, I'l follow you; and Sir, be comforted,
I will not leave till I finde some remorse;
Meane time let not want trouble you;
You shall not know it.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis not want I feare, but want of blessing
My knee was bent for; for mine Vncles state,
Which now I dare say out-weighes my fathers farre,
Confirmes my hopes as rich, as with my fathers,
His love excepted onely.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thy Vncles state, how for heavens love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: By his late marriage to the wealthiest widow
That London had, who has not onely made him
Lord of her selfe, but of her whole estate.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mother-a-pearle, I rejoyce in't: this newes
Is yet but young?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Fame will soone speake it loud, Sir

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This may helpe happily to make all peace;
But how have you parly'd with my daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Very well Father: We spake something, but did
Nothing at all; I requested him to pull me
A Catherin Peare, and had not I lookt to him
He would have mistooke and given me a Popperrin;
And to requite his kindenesse, I pluck'd him a Rose,
And he had almost prick'd my finger for my paines.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Well said Wag, are there sparkes kindled, quench
'M not for me, 'tis not a fathers roughnesse,
Nor doubtfull hazard of an Vncles kindenesse
Can me deterre; I must to your father.
Where (as a chiefe affaire) I'l once more moue,
And if I can returne him backe to love.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, you see I have made a speedy choyse,
And as swift a marriage; be it as it will,
I like the man, if his qualities afflict me,
I shall be happy in't.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I must not distaste, what I have help'd to make;
'Tis I that joyn'd you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: A good bargaine, I hope.
Roger, Where's your Master?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: The Good man of the house is within forsooth.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not your Master, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Tis hard of digestion: Yes, my Master is within;
Hee masters you therefore I must be
Content: You have long'd for Crosses a good
While, and now you are like to be
Farther off them than e'r you were; For
I'm affraid, your good husband will leave
You ne'r a crosse i'th' house to blesse you with.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Well Sir, I shall be blest in't: But where is he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Where he has mistaken the place a little,
Being his wedding-day; he is in nomine,
When he should be in re.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And where's that?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: In your Counting-house; If he were a kinde
Husband, he would have bin in another
Counting-house by this time: hee's tumbling
Over all his money bags yonder; you shall
Heare of him in the bowling Alley againe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why Sir, all is his, and at his
Dispose; who shall dare to thwart him?

div.stage: Enter Stephen with bills and bonds.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Looke where he comes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: How now, Sweete-heart? what hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I finde much debts belonging to you, Sweete;
And my care must be now to fetch them in;

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Ha, ha; prethee doe not mistake thy selfe,
Nor my true purpose; I did not wed to thrall,
Or binde thy large expence, but rather to adde
A plenty to that liberty; I thought by this,
Thou would'st have stuft thy pockets full of Gold,
And throwne it at a hazard; made Ducks and Drakes,
And baited fishes with thy silver flyes;
Lost, and fetcht more: why this had bin my joy;
Perhaps at length thou would'st have wast'd
My store; why, this had bin a blessing to
Good for me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Content thee, Sweete, those daies are gone,
I, even from my memorie;
I have forgot that e'r I had such follies,
And I'l not call 'm backe: my eares are bent
To keepe your state, and give you all content.
Roger, goe, call your fellow-servants up to me,
And to my Chamber bring all bookes of debt;
I will o're-looke, and cast up all accounts,
That I may know the weight of all my cares,
And once a yeere give up my stewardship.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Now you may see what hastie matching is;
You had thought to have bin vext, and now
You cannot: You have marryed a husband,
That, Sir reverence of the title, now being my Master in law,
I doe thinke hee'l proove the miserablest, covetous
Rascall, that ever beate beggar from his gate. But
'Tis no matter; time was when you were fairely
Offered, if you would have tooke it; you might have had
Other matches y'faith, if it had pleas'd you; and those
That would have crost you; I would have sold away
All that ever you had had; have kept two or three
Whores at liverie under your nose; have turn'd you out
In your smocke, and have us'd you like a woman; where
As now, if you'd hang your selfe, you can have none of
These blessings: but 'tis well enough, now you must
Take what followes.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I'm new to seeke for crosses, the hopes I meant
Turne to despaire, and smoother in content.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O Nephew are you come: The welcom'st wish
That my heart has; This is my kinsman, Sweete.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Let him be largely texted in your love,
That all the Citty may reade it fairely;
You cannot remember me, and him forget.
We were alike to you in poverty.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I should have beg'd that bounty of your love,
Though you had scanted me to have given't him;
For we are one, I an Vncle Nephew,
He an Nephew Vncle. But my Sweete selfe,
My slow request you have anticipated
With proffer'd kindenesse; and I thanke you for it.
But how, kinde Cozin, does your father use you?
Is your name found againe within his bookes?
Can he reade son there?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: 'Tis now blotted quite: for by the violent instigation
Of my cruell Stepmother, his Vowes and Othes
Are stampt against me, ne'r to acknowledge me,
Ne'r to call, or blesse me as a childe;
But in his brow, his bounty, and behaviour
I reade it almost plainelie.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Cozin, grieve not at it; that father lost at home,
You shall finde here; and with the losse of his inheritance,
You meete another amply profferd you;
Be my adopted son, no more my kinsman;
So that this borrowed bounty doe not stray
From your consent.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Call it not borrowed, Sir, 'tis all your owne;
Here 'fore this reverent man I make it knowne,
Thou art our childe as free by adoption,
As deriv'd from us by conception, birth, and
Propinquitie; Inheritour to our full substance.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You were borne to blesse us both,
My knee shall practise a sons duty
Even beneath sons, giving you all
The comely dues of parents: yet not
Forgetting my duty to my father;
Where e'r I meet him, he shall have my knee,
Although his blessing ne'r returne to me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come then my dearest son, I'l now give thee
A taste of my love to thee; be thou my deputy,
The Factour and disposer of my businesse;
Keepe my accounts, and order my affaires;
They must be all your owne; for you, deere Sweet,
Be merry, take your pleasure, at home, abroad;
Visit your neighbours; ought that may seeme good
To your owne will, downe to the Country ride;
For cares and troubles lay them all aside,
And I will take them up, it's fit that weight
Should now lye all on me: take thou the height
Of quiet and content, let nothing grieve thee;
I brought thee nothing else, and that I'le give thee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Will the Tide never turne? Was ever woman
Thus burden'd with unhappy happinesse?
Did I from Ryot take him, to waste my goods,
And he strives to augment it? I did mistake him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Spoyle not a good Text with a false Comment;
All these are blessings, and from heaven sent;
It is your husbands good, hee's now transform'd
To a better shade, the prodigall's return'd.
Come, come, know joy, make not abundance scant;
You 'plaine of that which thousand women want.

div.stage: Enter Alderman Bruine, Master Foster and Factors bearing o'r bags.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So, so, haste home good Lads, and returne for the rest.
Would they were cover'd, George, 'tis too Publicke
Blazon of my estate; but 'tis no matter now;
I'l bring it abroad againe e'r it be long.
Sir, I acknowledge receit of my still halfe debt,
Twelve thousand five hundred pounds; it now remaines
You seale those writings, as assurance for the rest,
And I am satisfyed for this time.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Pray stay Sir, I have bethought me, let me once
Throw Dice at all, and either be a compleate
Merchant, or wracke my estate for ever:
Heare me Sir, I have of wares that are now vendible,
So much as will defray your utmost penny;
Will you accept of them, and save this charge
Of wax and parchment.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Be they vendible Sir? I am your Chapman:
What are they, Master Foster?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Broad clothes, Karsies, Cutchineale, such
As will not stay two dayes upon your hands.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I finde your purpose; you'd have your Ware.
Houses empty for the receit of your full fraught;
I'l be your furtherer, make so your rates, that
I may be no looser.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I have no other end, Sir; let our
Factors peruse and deale for both.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Mine is return'd; George, here's a new businesse,
You and Richard must deale for some commodities
Betwixt us, if you finde 'm even gaine or but
Little losse, take carriage presently and carry 'm home.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: Richard, have you any further newes yet from our shipping?

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Not yet, Sir; but by account from the last, when they
Put from Dover, this Tide should bring them into
Saint Catharins Poole; the winde has bin friendly.

sp.speaker: O, Fost.
sp.l: Listen their arrivall, and bid the Gunner speake it
In his lowd thunder all the Citty over;
Tingle the Merchants eares at the report
Of my abundant wealth; now goe with George.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I shall doe both, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: I must plainely now confesse, Master Alderman, I shall gaine much by you. The halfe of your Ship defrayes my full cost.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Beshrew me if I grudge it, being my selfe a Sufficient gainer by my venter, Sir.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Still flowes the Tide of my unhappinesse,
The stars shoote mischiefe, and every houre
Is criticall to me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: How now woman? wrackt in the heaven of felicity?
sp.l: What ayl'st thou?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I thinke the divel's mine enemy

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I hope so too; his hate is better than his friendship.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Your brother, your good brother, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What of him? hee's in Ludgate againe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No, hee's in Hye-gate; he struts it bravely,
An Aldermans pace at least.

sp.speaker: O, Fost.
sp.l: Why, these are Oracles, doubtfull Enigma's!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why, I'm sure you have heard the newes;
Hee's marryed forsooth.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: How, marryed? no woman of repute would choose So slightly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: A woman, in whose brest, I had thought had liv'd
The very quintessence of discretion; and who is't,
Thinke you? nay you cannot ghesse, though I should give
You a day to riddle it; 'tis my Gossip, Man, the rich
Widdow of Cornehill.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Fye, fye, 'tis fabulous.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Are you my husband? then is shee his wife;
How will this upstart beggar shoulder up,
And take the wall of you? his new found pride
Will know no eldership.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: But wife, my wealth will five times double his, e'r
This Tide ebbe againe; I wonder I heare not the
Brazen Cannon proclame the Arrivall of my
Infinite substance.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: But beggars will be proud of little, and shoulder at the best.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Let him first pay his old score, and then reckon;
But that shee:â€”

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, that's it mads me too.
Would any woman, lesse to spite her selfe,
So much prophane the sacred name of wedlock:
A Dove to couple with a Storke, or a Lambe a Viper?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Content thee; Forgive her; shee'l doe so no more;
She was a rich widdow, a wife hee'l make her poore.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: So Sir, you have clos'd it well; if so ill it prove,
Leave it to proofe, and wish not misery
Vnto your enemy looke, here he comes.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: You say true 'tis my enemy indeede.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Save you Master Alderman, I have some businesse with you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: With me, Sir, and most welcome, I rejoyce to see you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Doe you observe, Sir; he will not know you now?
Iockeye's a Gentleman now.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Well fare rich widowes, when such beggars flourish;
But ill shall they fare, that florish o're such beggars.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: He laughes at you.
