sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: No wonder, woman, he would doe that in Ludgate;
But 'twas when his kind Nephew did relieve him:
I shall heare him cry there againe shortly.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Oysters, new Walfleet Oysters.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: The Gentleman is merry.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: No, no, no; he does this to spight me; as who Should say, I had bin a fish-wife in my younger dayes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fye, fye, Gentlemen, this is not well;
My eares are guilty to heare such discords.
Looke, Master Foster; turne your eye that way;
There's duty unregarded, while envy struts
In too much state: believe me, Gentlemen,
I know not which to chide first.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What Idoll kneeles that heritique too.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Rise Boy; thou art now my son, and owest no knee
To that unnaturall; I charge you rise.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Doe Sir, or turne your adoration that way;
You were kind to him in his tatter'd state;
Let him requite it now.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Doe, doe, we have pai'd for't aforehand,

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I would I were devided in two halfes, so that Might reconcile your harsh devision

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Proud Sir, this son which you have alienated
For my loves sake, shall by my loves bounty
Ride side by side in the best Equipage
Your scornes dare patterne him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I, I, a beggars gallop up and downe.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I, 'tis up now, the next step downe.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I laugh at your envy Sir, my businesse is to you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Good Sir, speake of any thing but this.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Sir, I am furnishing some shipping forth,
And want some English traffique, Broad-clothes, Karsies
Or such like, my voyage is to the Straites:
If you can supply me, Sir, I'l be your Chapman.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: That I shall soone resolve you, Sir;
Come hither George.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: This is the rich Merchant-man;

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: That's neither grave not wife;

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Who will kill a man at Tiburne shortly.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: By Carts that may arise; Or if the hangman dye,
He may have his office.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then you have bargain'd, George.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: And the Ware carryed home, Sir; you must looke
To be little gainer; but lose you cannot.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis all I desire from thence, Sir I can furnish you
With Wares I lately from your brother bought;
Please you goe see them, for I would faine divide you,
Since I can win no nearer friendship.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l goe with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Take your adoption with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I crave but your blessing with me, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: 'Tis my curse then; get thee out of mine eye.
Th'art a beame in't, and I'le teare it out e'r it
Offend to looke on thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Goe, goe, Sir; follow your Vncle-father,
Helpe him to spend, what thrift has got together;
'Twilbe charity in you to spend,
Because your charity it was to lend.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My charity; you can a vertue name.
And teach the use, yet never knew the same

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: See wife, here comes Richard.
Now listen, and heare me crown'd
The wealthiest London Merchant.
Why dost thou looke so sadly?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Why dost not speake; hast lost thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I never could speake worse.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Why, thy voyce is good enough.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: But the worst accent Sir, that ever you heard,
I speake a Screechowles note. Oh you have made
The most unhappiest bargaine that ever Merchant did!

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ha? what can so balefull be, as thou would'st seeme
To make by this sad prologue? I am no traytor
To confiscate my goods: speake, what e'r it be.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: I would you could conceite it, that I might not speake it.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Dally not with torments, sinke me at once.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Now y'ave spoke it halfe; 'tis sinking I must treate of
Your ships are all sunke.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hah!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: O thou fatall Raven; Let me pull thine eyes out for this
sp.l: Sad croake.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hold woman; hold prethee; 'tis none of his fault.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis thine, thou wretch; and therefore
Let me turne my vengeance all on thee; thou
Hast made hot haste to empty all my Ware-houses,
And made roome for that the sea hath drunk before
Thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Vndone for ever! Where could this mischiefe fail?
Were not my ships in their full pride at Dover;
And what English Carybda's has the divell dig'd
To swallow nearer home.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.l: Even in the Mouth, and entrance of the Thames
They were all cast away.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Dam up thy Mouth from any farther
Mischievous relation.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Some men were sav'd, but not one penny-worth of goods.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Even now thy balefull utterance was chok'd,
And now it runs too fast; thou fatall Bird no more.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: May Serpents breed, and fill this fatall Streame,
And poyson her for ever.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O curse not, they come too fast!

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Let me curse somewhere, Wretch, or else I'l throw
Them all on thee; 'tis thou, ungodly Slave,
That art the marke unto the wrath of Heaven:
I thriv'd e'r I knew thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prethee split me too.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I would I could; I would I had never seene thee;
For I ne'r saw houre of comfort since I knew thee.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Vndone for ever, my credit I have crackt,
To buy a Venture, which the Sea has sok'd;
What worse can woe report.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Yes worse than all,
Thy enemies will laugh, and scorne thy fall.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Be it the worst then; that place I did assigne
My unthrifty brother, Ludgate, must now be mine.
Breake, and take Ludgate.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Take Newgate rather.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I scorn'd my child, now he may scorne his father.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Scorne him still.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I will; would he my wants relieve,
I'd scorne to take what he would yeeld to give:
My heart be still my friend, although no other;
I'l scorn the helpe of either son, or brother,
My portion's begging now; seldome before.
In one sad houre, was man so rich and poore.

div.head: Actus Quartus.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Iane, Godfry Speedewell, and Master Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: GEntlemen, my Father's not within; please
You to walke a turne or two in the garden,
Hee'l not be long.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.p: Your father, Mistris Iane, I hope you have observation in you,
sp.l: And know our humours; we come not a wooing to your Father.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: Experience must beare with folly; Thou art all innocent,
sp.l: And thy name is Lambskin; grave Sapience guides me,
And I care not a pin for thy squibs, and thy Crackers,
My old dry wood shall make a lusty bonefire, when
Thy greene Chips shall lye hissing in the Chimney-
Corner. Remember Mistris, I can make you a Lady by
Mine owne experience.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Prethee doe not stand troubling the Gentlewoman
With thy musty sentences, but let her love be laid
Downe betwixt us like a paire of Cudgells, and into
Whose hands she thrusts the weapons first, let him
Take up the Bucklers.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: A match betweene us

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Must I be stickler then?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: We are both to run at the Ring of your setting
Vp, and you must tell us who deserves most favour.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: But will you stand both at my disposing?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Else let me never stand but in a Pillory.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: You love me both you say?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: By this hand.â€”

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Hand? Zoundes by the foure and twenty Elements.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Pray spare your oathes; I doe believe you doe
You would not else make all this stir to wooe.
Sir Godfry, you are a knight both tough and old,
A rotten building cannot long time hold.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Speedewell, live well, dye well, and be hang'd well.
Revenge your coppy well, your experience will not carry it else.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Y'are rich too, at least your selfe so say;
What though? y'are but a gilded man of clay.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: A man of Ginger-bread; y'faith I could finde in
My heart to eate him.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Should I wed you, the fire with frost must marry
Ianuary and May; I for a younger tarry.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: That's l; introth I'le be thy young Lambskin; thou shalt
Finde me as innocent as a sucking Dove: speake, Sweete
Mistris, am I the youth in a basket?

sp.speaker: Iane
sp.l: You are the sweete youth Sir, whose pretty eyes
Would make me love; but you must first be wise.

sp.speaker: Speede.
sp.l: Ah, hah, is your coxcombe cut? I see experience must
Boord this faire Pinnace: a word in private,

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I'l have no words in private, unlesse I heare too.

div.stage: Enter Master Bruine, Stephen and Robin.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, we'l make few
Winds about it; Merchants in
Bargaining must not, like Souldiors lying at a siege, stay
Moneths, weekes, daies, but strike at the first parley.
Broad-clothes, and Woolls, and other rich Commodities, I
Lately from your brother bought, are all your owne.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Then be not angry gentle Sir,
If now a string be touch'd, which hath too long
Sounded so harshly over all the Citty;
I now would winde it to a musicall height.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Good Master Alderman I thinke that string will still
Ostend mine eare; You meane the jarring
Twixt me and my brother?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: In troth the same.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I hate no poyson like that brothers name

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: O Fye, not so.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Vncivill churle, when all his sailes were up.
And that his proud heart danc'd on golden wayes:

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: As heaven be thank'd it still does.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet Sir, then I being sunke, and drown'd in mine
Owne misery, he would not cast out a poore line
Of thred to bring me to the shore; I had bin
Dead, and might have starv'd for him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: A better fate Sir, stood at your elbow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: True Sir; this was he that lifted me from want
And misery, whose cruell father for that
Good cast him away; scorning his name and blood;
Lopt from his side this branch that held me deere.
For which hee's now my son, my joy, my heire,
But for his father hang him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Fye, fye.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come, come, live in more charity, he is your brother;
If that name offend, I'l sing that tune no more.
Yonder's my daughter busie with her suitors;
Wee'l visit them. Now Iane, bid your friends
Welcome.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: They must be welcome Sir, that come with you;
To thee ten thousand welcomes still are due.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: My sweete Mistris.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Lounds Sir knight, we have stood beating the Bush
And the bird's flowne away; this Citty
Bowler has kist the Mistris at first cast.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: How fare yee Gentlemen, what cheere Sir knight?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: An adventurer still Sir, to this new found land.

sp.speaker: Lamb
sp.l: He sayles about the point Sir, but he cannot put in yet.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: The winde may turne Sir. A word Master Foster.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: You see Sir Speedwell, what Card is turn'd
Vp for trumpe; I hold my life this spruce
Cittizen will forestall the market, Oh
These briske factors, are notable firkers.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: I doubt Sir, he will play the merchant with us.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They both are suitors Sir, yet both shoote wide;
My daughter sure must be your kinsmans bride.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l give her a wedding Ring on that condition
And put a Stone in't worth a thousand pounde, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You have my hand and heart too't, be she pleas'd so.

sp.speaker: Lamb
sp.p: S'foote, let's shew our selves Gallants, or Gallymawfryes:
sp.l: Shall we be bury'd by a Cockney. A word
My faire Zoardes; Doe you see Sir, here be those
That have gon a fishing, and can give you a
Gudgion.

sp.speaker: Rob..
sp.l: You were best goe fish for better manners, or I
Shall bob for Eles with you.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Zoundes are you a striker? Draw, Sir knight.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Not in my house; I pray be quiet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He dares not doe't abroad believe me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Now by my life my Boy, for this brave spirit
I hug thee in mine armes: lose life and limbes
E'r thou forsake thy love.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Hee's no Rivall here Sir; has struck me,
And we are Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: And heare yee, Sir, let him seeke out his equalls;
For some of us are in danger to make her
A Lady shortly: I know what I speake; what
I speake, I'l doe; yet I'l doe nothing, but
What comes from grave experience.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Speake what you please Sir, hee's a Gentleman as
Good at either of you both, and shall in lists of
Love for such a bed-fellow, brave him that dares,
And here lay downe more gold to win her love,
Than both your states are worth.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Ha? doe you know us, Sir? You grow too bold;
My experience now hath found you;
You were once a tatter'd fellow, your name is
Foster; have you such gold to give?

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Yes, yes, has won it betting at the bowling Alleyes,
Or at the Pigeon-holes in the Garden Alleyes.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: You are muddy Groomes to upbraid mee with that scorne,
Which vertue now gilds over; Pray yee Gentlemen
May I request your names.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Our names are in the Heralds bookes I warrant you
My name is Innocent Lambskin; and this Knight,
Simply though he stands here, is knowne to be
Sir Godfry Speedewell.

sp.speaker: Step.
sp.l: Well may he Speede Sir; Lambskin and Speedewell,
Ha? Is't so? I thinke I shall give you a medicine
To purge this itch of love, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No itch neither Sir, we have no scabs here,
But your selfe and your Cozin.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Very good Sir, my little Lambskin. I have you
Here in Sheepeskin; looke you, 'tis so y'faith.
See, Master Alderman, these two crackt Gallants
Are in severall bonds to my Predecessor
For a debt of full two thousand apiece.
Cozin, fetch me a Serjeant straite.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: O let him, I have a protection, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l try that, Sir.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: A Serjeant? Nay, then experience must worke,
Legs be strong and bold; when Serjeants waite
At feasts, the cheere's but cold.
I'l shift for one.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Knight, knight; S'foote if an errand Knight
Run away, I were an arrand Asse to tarry,
And be catch'd in the lime-bush: I love the
Wench well; but if they have no hole to
Place me in, but the hole in the Counter,
I'l be gone and leave'm; that's flat

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: You have scar'd the suitors from the marke, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I am glad on't Sir; they are but such as seeke
To build their rotten state on you, and with your
Wealth to underprop their weakenesse;
Believe me, reverend Sir, I had much rather
You'd venter that my Cuz might call you father.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: We'l talke of that anon; See Sir,
Here comes your wife, the theame
Of all her time, with goodnesse mixt, the happy
Woman that was never vext; y'are welcome
Mrs Foller.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thanke yee Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wife, your two debtors were here but now;
And Lambskin; A Wolfe could not have torne
ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ Lambskin worse, than the bare name
Of a Serjeant: the very thought made them both
To take their heeles and run away.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Las, they are poore and leane, and being so;
Kill them not till they are fatter.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: At thy girdle, Sweete, hangs the keyes, to
Lock the prison dores or let them loose:
'Twas my intent onely in way of mirth to
Rid them from the presence of Mistris Iane,
That our adopted son might have no bar
Vnto his love.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The match is faire; and were that knot once tyed,
I'd send some Angels to attend the bride.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Sir, here's your factor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Are the wares ready.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes, and deliver'd Sir, to Master Foster's servants,
Who conveyed them in Carts to the Custome.
House, there to be shipt; but going with them,
Sir, I met ill newes.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Ill newes? what ist?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Old Master Foster's ships so richly laden,
By strange misfortune, Sir, are cast away.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Now heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Oh mee!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How? cast away; where?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis impossible; they rid at Dover safe,
When he out-bought my full share in the fraught,
And paid me downe neare thirty thousand pounds
In wares and money.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Which had he not done, you had lost your venture:
By Master Foster's owne appointment Sir, they weighed
Their Anchors up, and so to come for London;
But by a mercilesse storme they all were
Swallowed, even in the Theames mouth; yet
The men were sav'd, but all the goods were lost.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my poore father! This losse will breake his backe.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Ha? What's that to you? if in my favour you'l
Sit warme, then bury all love to him,
Nay duty, heare you Sir? What shed'st thou teares
For him, that had no care to see thy heart drop
Blood? he was unnaturall, and heaven hath
Iustly now rewarded him.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: 'Tis a most strange Fate; he needes would buy my
Part at any rate, he car'd not what; and now all's lost,

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Greedy desire he swallowed, and now is swallowed:
'Tis but his hyre; and I'l not pitty it, no more
Than he, in his abundance, did my misery.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I grieve for my poore Gossip, his good wife,
She never met good fortune all her life,
And this will breake her heart-strings:
In good sooth I'l goe and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: In good sooth you shall not,
Nor him, nor her at this time, gentle wife;
He scorn'd me in his height, now being poore,
If that he needes my helpe, he knowes my doore.
Sir, we'l for this time leave you, at fitter leasure,
We'l have this marriage talk't of.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: At your owne good pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come wife; Goe not to see your father, Sir, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Iane, bring your friends toth' dore.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'l helpe my father, though my selfe grow poore.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Where's my Factor?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: What, are the square stones, and timber
Brought as I appointed?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, and the workemen, that daily ply the
Worke, are in number fourescore at least.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: My vowes flew up to heaven, that I would make
Some pious worke in the brasse booke of Fame,
That might till Doomesday lengthen out my name.
Neare Norton Folgate therefore have I bought
Ground to erect this house, which I will call
And dedicate, Saint Marie's Hospitall;
And when 'tis finish'd, o'r the gates shall stand
In capitall letters, these words fairely graven
For I have given the worke and house to heaven
And cal'd it, Domus Dei, Gods house;
For in my zealous faith I know full well,
Where good deedes are, there heaven it selfe doth dwell.

div.stage: Enter Old Foster, Richard his factor, and the Keeper of Ludgate

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Good Sir, resolve not thus; returne againe,
Your debts are not so great, that you should yeeld
Your body thus to prison unconstrain'd.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I will not trust the iron hearts of men;
My credit's lost, my wealth the Sea has swallowed,
Wrack'd at my dore, even in the mouth o'th' Thames.
Oh my misfortune! never man like me
Was so throwne downe, and cast to misery.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Deare Sir, be patient.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prethee get thee gone, and with thy diligence
Assist thy Mistris to keepe that little left, to
Helpe her selfe, whil'st here in Ludgate I secure
My body from Writs, Arrests, and Executions,
Which, well I know, my cruell Creditors will
Thunder on me. Goe, get thee gone; if what
Is left they'l take, doe thou agree;
If not, I am here resolv'd to stay and dye.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: I'l doe my best Sir, to procure your peace.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Do so. Come Sir, I yeeld my selfe your prisoner,
You are the Keeper of this Ludgate.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Yes Sir, your name is registred among the prisoners.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: So, I have seene the faire outside of this tombe before;
This goodly apple has a rotten core.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: As all prisons have, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I prethee bar me of no priviledge due to a free
Citizen; Thou knowest me well?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Yes Master Foster, and I sorrow for your losses,
Yet doubt not but your son and brother.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O speake not of them! doe not kisse and kill me:
I have no son nor brother that esteemes me,
And I for ever hate their memory:
Prethee no more; I am come sicke into a
Bad Inne, and looke for worse attendance,
I have taken a surfeit of misfortunes, and here
Must swallow pills
With poyson to recure me: I am sea-sicke, Sir,
And heave my hands to heaven; ne'r to so
Low an ebbe was Foster driven.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: There be some Fees to pay, Sir, at your comming in.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: So, so, if this old Wall-nut-tree, after all this
Cudgelling, have but one cluster left, thou shalt
Have that too; if not, take off these leaves that
Cover me; pull off these white locks; rend them from
My head, and let me in my woes be buried.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: 'Las, Sir, this house is poore.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I thinke no lesse;
For rich men seldome meete with such distresse,
Well, well, what booke must I reade over now?
What servile Oare must I be tyed to here,
Slave-like to tug within this christian Galley?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, being the youngest prisoner in the house,
You must beg at the iron grate above,
As others doe for your reliefe and their's.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: For a beggar to beg, Sir, is no shame;
And for the iron grate, it beares an embleme
Of iron-hearted Creditors, that force men lye
In loathsome prisons thus to starve and die.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Who would you speake with, Sir?
Oh, cry you mercy; 'tis his sonne:
I'l leave them.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O torment to my soule! What mak'st thou here?
Cannot the picture of my misery
Be drawne, and hung out to the eyes of men,
But thou must come to scorne and laugh at it?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Deare Sir, I come to thrust my backe under your loade,
To make the burden lighter.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hence from my sight, dissembling villaine; goe,
Thine Vncle sends defiance to my woe,
And thou must bring it: Hence, thou Basyliske,
That kil'st me with mine eyes: nay, never kneele;
These scornefull mocks more than my woes I feele.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alas, I mocke yee not; but come in love,
And naturall duty Sir, to beg your blessing;
And for mine Vncleâ€”

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Him, and thee I curse,
Pl starve, e'r I eate bread from his purse,
Or from thy hand; Out villaine, tell that Cur,
Thy barking Vncle, that I lye not here
Vpon my bed of ryot, as he did,
Coverd with all the villanies, which man
Had ever woven; tell him I lye not so,
It was the hand of heaven strucke me thus low,
And I doe thanke it. Get thee gone, I say,
Or I shall curse thee, strike thee; Prethee away;
Or if thou'lt laugh thy fill at my poore state,
Then stay, and listen to the prison grate,
And heare thy father, an old wretched man,
That yesterday had thousands, beg and cry,
To get a penny: Oh my misery!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Deere Sir, for pitty heare me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Vpon my curse I charge no nearer come,
I'l be no father to so vild a Son.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my abortive fate!
Why for my good am I thus pay'd with hate?
From this sad place of Ludate here I freed
An Vncle, and I lost a father for it;
Now is my father here, whom if I succour,
I then must lose my Vncle's love and favour.
My Father once being rich, and Vncle poore,
I him relieving was thrust forth of dores;
Baffled, revil'd, and disinherited:
Now mine owne Father here must beg for bread,
Mine Vncle being rich, and yet if I
Feede him, my selfe must beg. Oh misery,
How bitter is thy taste! yet I will drinke
Thy strongest poyson; fret what mischiefe can,
I'l feede my Father, though, like the Pellican,
I pecke mine owne brest for him.

div.stage: Old Foster, and above at the grate, a box hanging downe.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, one penny to buy a
Loafe of bread for the tender mercy!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O me my shame! I know that voyce full well;
I'l help thy wants, although thou curse me still.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread; some Christian man send back
Your charity to an number of poore prisoners;
One penny for the tender mercy.
The hand of heaven reward you, gentle Sir,
Never may you want, never feele misery;
Let blessings in unnumbred measure grow,
And fall upon your head where e'r you goe.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O happy comfort! curses to the ground
First strucke me, now with blessings I am crown'd.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, for the tender mercy; one
Penny for a loafe of bread.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I'l buy more blessings; Take thou all my store,
I'l keepe no coyne; and see my father poore.

sp.speaker: O. Fost,
sp.l: Good Angels guard you, Sir, my prayers shalbe
That heaven may blesse you for this charity.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: If he knew me, sure he would not say so;
Yet I have comfort if by any meanes
I get a blessing from my fathers hands:
How cheape are good prayers? A poore penny buyes
That, by which man up in a minute flies,
And mounts to heaven.
Oh me, mine Vncle sees me!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Now Sir, what make you here so neere the prison?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I was going, Sir, to buy meate for a poore bird I have,
That sits so sadly in the Cage of late,
I thinke he'l dye for sorrow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: So Sir, your pitty will not quit you paines, I feare me;
I shall finde that bird I thinke to be that churlish
Wretch, your father, that now has taken
Shelter here in Ludgate; Goe too, Sir, urge me
Not, you'd best; I have given you warning:
Fawne not on him nor come not neare him,
If you'l have my love.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Las Sir, that Lambe
Were most unnaturall that should hate the Dam.

sp.speaker: Ste,
sp.l: Lambe me no Lambs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good Vncle; 'las you know when you lay here.
I succour'd you, so let me now helpe him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes, as he did me,
To laugh and triumph at my misery;
You freed me with his gold, but 'gainst his will:
For him I might have rotted, and laine still;
So shall he now.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Alack the day!

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: If him thou pitty, 'tis thine owne decay:

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Bread, bread, some charitable man remember
The poore prisoners; bread for the render mercy,
One penny.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O listen Vncle; that's my poore father's voyce.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: There let him howle; Get you gon, and come not neare him

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my soule! what tortours dost thou feele?
Earth neare shall find, a son so true,
Yet forc'd to be unkind.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Well, go thy waies, thou patterne of true vertue;
My heart is full, I could even weepe, and much adoe I had to forbeare,
To heare a brother begging in a Iayle,
That but e'r while spred up a lofty sayle
As proudly as the best: Oh, 'twere a sin
Vnpardonable in me, should I not succour him?
Yes, I will doe't, yet closely it shalbe done,
And he not know from whence his comforts come.
What ho, Keeper there, a word I praye.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: What's your pleasure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: What's he that at the grate there beg'd even now.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: One Master Foster, Sir, a decayed Citizen new
Come in. Cry you mercy Sir, you know him
Better than my selfe, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I should doe, knew he me as I would know
Him: prethee take him from the grate,
And that no more he stand to beg,
There's ten pound to pay his score, and
Take off all his wants; if he demand
Who sends it, tell him, 'tis thine owne free
Hand to lend him money.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Well Sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Spend what he will, my purse shall pay it all;
And at his parting hence, the poorest prisoner,
And all free Citizens that live in Ludgate,
Shall blesse his comming in; I'l for his sake
Doe something now, that whil'st this Citty stands,
Shall keepe the Foster's name engraven so high,
As no blacke storme shall cloud their memory.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Heaven blesse your purpose, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Stephens Wife, and her sister Old Fosters Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sister, there's no way to make sorrow light
But in the noble bearing; be content;
Blowes given from heaven are our due punishment;
All ship wracks are no drownings, you see buildings
Made fairer from their Ruines; he that I married,
The brother to your husband, lay, you know,
On the same bed of misery, yet now
Hee's ranckt with the best Citizens.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O you were borne to wealth and
Happinesse; I, to want and scorne!

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Come, I will worke my husband; stay this griefe.
The longest sorrow findes at last reliefe.
Now Sir, your businesse.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Marry mistris here are two creatures
scarce able to make one man, desires to speake
With you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What are they, know their names.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Nay, I know that already; the one is a
Thing that was plac'd into the
World, by the head and shoulders to be
Wondered at, and 'tis cald a knight; the other
Is a coach-horse of the same over-ridden race;
And that's a foolish Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O, they are my old debtors, Speedwell and Lambskin
Goe call them in, and my gentle sister
Comfort your selfe and my imprison'd brother,
To whom commend me give to him this gold,
What good I can, I'l doe for him be bold.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: May heavenly blessings guard you from all ill:
Never was woman vext as I am still.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Now good Sir Godfry and Master Innocent.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: I put my innocent case into your hands
Mistris, as a simple country Clyent thrusts his money
Into a Lawyers, who stands upon no great
Tearms to take it.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.p: We come about the old businesse, the sicknesse of the purse Lady

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: And they'd be loth to keepe their beds it'th' counter
Mistris; they are affraid of Serjeants, Master Lambskin,
Knowes that Mace is a binder.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No truly it makes me loose for I never smell it, though
It be two streetes off, but it gives me a stoole presently,

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I, you have bin a loose liver alwayes,
'Tis time to looke to you.

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Fayre Lady, we are your debtors, and owe you mony.
Experience tels us that our bonds are forfeit,
For which your husband threatned to arrest us; my
Shoulders love no such clappings, I love
Tobacco, but would be loth to drinke in Woodstreet.
Pipes; some money we will pay ere we goe hence:
I speake you see with grave experience.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I know it well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Had not your husband (when we went about fowling
For the Aldermans daughter) driven away the Bird
We might have bidden you to a better breakefast;
But now you must take what we can set before you.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I am content to doe so: you shall finde
Nor me nor my husband carry a griping minde.
Now Cuz, where's your Vncle.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: He's hard at hand, I saw him comming
With the Lord Maior and Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: Zoundes Knight, if the Maior come
The shoulder clappers are not farre off.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O feare not, I'l be your surety Sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Doe you not smell Poultry ware, Sir Godfry?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Most horribly, I'l not endure the sent on't.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Vpon my trust none here shall doe you wrong;
What is his businesse with the Alderman?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: About the entertainment of the King
That meanes to visit London.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Saw you your sad father?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I did; would I might never see man more
Since he so hates my sight; the prison doore,
Which gapes for commers in, that mouth of hell,
Shut me out with a churlish cold farewell;
After my fathers most unnaturall part
Was plaid on miseries stage, mine Vncle comes
In thunder on me, threatning with blacke stormes
To nayle me to the earth, if I releeved my
Poore old father.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Here's my master now Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, y'are both welcome,
Have you paid this money on your bonds yet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Not yet Sir, but here they come like honest Gentlemen
To take some order for it: good Sweetheart
Shall it be put to me.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Doe as you please;
In all thy deeds th'rt govern'd with good starres,
Therefore if thou cry'st peace, I'le not raise warres.
E'ne order it how thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thanke ye Sir; then tell me Gentlemen,
What present money can you pay?

sp.speaker: Speed.
sp.l: Two hundred pound we can lay downe.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: And take up seven times as much if we knew
Where to get it; but there's our lamentable ease:
Mistris, if you strip us any neerer, you'l strip the
Skin and all I'le assure you,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: We'l sheare no sheepe so close.

sp.speaker: Lamb.
sp.l: No sheepe forsooth, but a poore innocent Lambskin.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: You should be a Calfe by your white face.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: All your two thousand pound Gentlemen we quit,
For your two hundred: goe pay the money to
My Cuz, and receive your two bonds canceld:
Say Sir, are ye content.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wife I must stand to the arbitrement.
Goe Cozin, receive their
Money, and Sirra make them drinke.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I'le make them drinke if they will; come
Gallants empty your bags, and I'l bumbast
Your bellies; this leane Gentleman lookes
As if he had no lining in's guts, I could
Take him by the leg and hurle him into
The dog-house.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How now sweet wife, what art thou
Musing on?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I must come a wooing to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: A wooing sweet, for what?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: For your brother; Oh 'tis unmeet
For soules fram'd by one square to grow uneven,
'Tis like a warre 'mongst the great lights of heaven,
One cannot lose his beauty, but the other
Suffers ecclipse; so brother against brother.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Wouldst have me kisse him that would kill me.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would you kill a man lying at your feet:
Doe good for ill.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thy songs are Angels tunes, and on thy wings
I'l flye with thee to heaven.
Thou speakest as I would have thee;
His debts I have justly weighed, and finde them light.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: The easier then tane off.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou sayest most right,
But I of purpose keepe aloofe to try
My kinsman; whom I spied most dolefully
Hovering about the grate, where his father cry'd
With pitteous voyce, for bread; yet did I chide
And rayl'd against the Boy; but my heart sayes
( How ere my tongue) it was drown'd in teares,
To see such goodnesse in a sonne.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Such wheeles in childrens bosome seldome runne.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l lay a wager wife, that this two hundred pounde
Payd by these foolish fellowes, will by the Boy
Be given his father.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Troth would it might:

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: In doing me such wrong he does me right
Ludgate was once my dwelling, and to shew
That I true feeling of his misery knew;
Albeit long since blowne o're; so thou'lt consent,
Within that place I'l raise some monument,
Shall keepe our names alive till doomes-day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I gladly shall agree.
To any act that tends to charity.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Come, where's Mr. Foster? Oh you lose time Sir,
Not meeting fortune that comes to kisse you.
The Lord Maior and Aldermen stay at the Guildhall,
Expecting you, as well to set downe order
Touching the entertainement of the King,
As to elect you for the following yeere a Sheriffe of London.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Their loves out-strip my merit.
Yet since they lay that load on me, I'l beare it,
And wait in scarlet on my leige and King.
But pray resolve me, Master Alderman,
Why makes the King this visitation?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Troth Sir, to honour me, I thanke his highnesse,
Who with my Lord the Cardinall comes along
To see the dedication of my House,
Built for the weary travellers to rest in;
Where stands three hundred beds for their releefe,
With meat, drinke, and some money when they part,
Which I'l give freely with a willing heart.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: A pious, worthy, and religious act:
Come Sir, toth' Guildhall; Wife, looke to your
Kinsman, watch him neare; but doe not hinder
Him if he releeve his father: Come Master Alderman,
With such sweet incense up your offerings flye,
I'l build one Altar more to charity.

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Old Foster, his Wife, and Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keeper.
sp.l: COme, come, be merry Sir; doe as mourners doe at
Funerals, weare your Hat in your eyes, and
Laugh in your heart.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I have no such fat legacie left me,
To teach me how to play the hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: No? Why looke yee Sir, you shall want neither
Meate, drinke, money, nor any thing that the
House affords, or if any thing abroad like yee,
Sir, here's money, send for what you will Sir:
Nay, you shall beg no more at the Grate neither.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Ha? Is not this Ludgate?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: A Iayle, a prison, a tombe of men lock'd up;
Alive and buryed?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: 'Tis what you please to call it.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O, at what crevice then hath comfort
Like a Sun-beame crept? for all the doores
And windowes are of Iron, and barr'd to keepe
Her out; I had a limbe cut from my body
Deare to me as life; I had a son and brother too;
Oh griefe, they both would give me poyson first
In gold, before their hollow palmes ten
Drops should hold of natures drinke, cold water,
But to save my life one minute; whence
Should pitty come, when my best friends doe.
Beate it from this roome.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: No matter Sir, since you have good meat set
Before you, never aske who sent it; if heaven
Provide for you, and make the fowles of the
Ayre your. Cators, feed you fat, and be thankefull,
And so I leave you.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: The Keeper is your friend, and powres true balme
Into your smarting wounds; therefore deare
Husband endure the dressing with patience.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O wife, my losses are as numberlesse as the
Sea's sands that swallowed them. And shall
I in reckoning them, my sad griefes multiply?

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.p: You may Sir, but your dim eyes so thick with teares doe run.
sp.l: You cannot see from whence your comforts come,
Besides your debts being truly counted cannot
Be great.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.p: But all my wealth and state lyes in the seas Bottome.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: It againe may rise.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Oh never.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Good Sir, so hope, for I from heaven espy
An arme to plucke you from this misery.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Sir, there's one without desires to speake with you.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Goe send him in; none comes to doe me good
My wealth is lost, now let them take my blood.
Ha? what art thou? Call for the Keeper there
And thrust him out of doores, or locke me up.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: O 'tis your son, Sir.

sp.speaker: O. Fost
sp.l: I know him not:
I am no King, unlesse of scorne and woe,
Why kneel'st thou then; why dost thou mock me so?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O my deare father, hither am I come
Not like a threatning storme to encrease your wrack
For I would take all sorrowes from your backe
To lay them all on my owne.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Rise mischiefe, rise, away and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O if I be thus hatefull to your eye
I will depart, and wish I soone may dye;
Yet let your blessing, Sir, but fall on me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: My heart still hates thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Sweet husband.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Get you both gon;
That misery takes some rest that dwells alone;
Away thou villaine.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Heaven can tell, ake but your finger, I to make it
Well, would cut my hand off.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Hang thee, hang thee.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Destruction meete thee, turne the key there ho.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good Sir: I'm gone, I will not stay to grieve you:
Oh knew you (for your woes) what paines I feele,
You would not scorne me so. See Sir, to coole
Your heate of burning sorrow I have got
Two hundred pounds and glad it is my lot
To lay it downe, with reverence at your feete;
No comfort in the world to me is sweet,
Whil'st thus you live in moane.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Good troth Sir, I'l have none on't back,
Could but one penny of it save my life.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Yet stay and heare him; Oh unnaturall strife,
In a hard fathers bosome.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I see mine error now: oh can there grow
A Rose upon a Bramble? did there e'r flow
Poyson and health together in one tide?
I'm borne a man; reason may step aside.
And leade a father's love out of the way:
Forgive me, my good Boy, I went astray;
Looke, on my knees I beg it; not for joy
Thou bringst this golden rubbish, which I spurne
But glad in this, the heaven's mine eye balls turne,
And fixe them right to looke upon that face
Where love remaines with pitty, duty, grace.
Oh my deare wronged boy!

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Gladnesse o'rwhelmes my heart with joy I cannot speak

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Crosses of this foolish world.
Did never grieve my heart with torments more
Than it is now growne light,
With joy and comfort of this happy sight.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Yet wife, I disinherited this boy.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Your blessings all I crave.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And that enjoy for ever, evermore; my
Blessings fly, to pay thy vertues, love and charity.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: Here comes your brothers wife,
Welcome deare sister.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I thanke you; how fare you brother?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Better than your husband's hate could wish me,
That laughes to see my backe with sorrowes bow:
But I am rid of halfe my ague now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Had you an ague then?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Yes, and my heart had every houre a fit.
But now 'tas left me well, and I left it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O, 'tis well Cozin, what make you heare I pray?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: To support a weake house falling to decay.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Tis well, if you can doe't, and that the timber
You under-prop it with be all your owne.
Hearke Cuz, where's your Vncles mony?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Faith Aunt 'tis gone, but not at dice,
Nor drabbing.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sir, I believe with your Vncles gold your father
You relieve.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You are sav'd believing so, your beliefe's true.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You cut large thongs of that's another's due
And you will answer't ill: now in good troth
I laugh at this jest, much good doe them both:
My wager I had won, had I but layd.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: What has my poore boy done, that you have
Made so much blood rise in's cheekes?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Nothing deare brother, indeed all's well:
The course that he has runne I like and love,
Let him hold on the same;
A sons love to a father none can blame;
I will not leave your brother's iron heart
Till I have beate it soft with my intreates.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: 'Twill ne'r be musick 'tis so full of frets.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Frets make best musike: strings the higher
Rack'd sound sweetest.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And sound nothing when they are crackt,
As is his love to me, and mine to him.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I hope you both in smoother streames shall swim:
Hee's now the Sheriffe of London, and in counsell
Set at the Guildhall, in his scarlet Gowne
With Maior and Aldermen, how to receive the King,
Who comes to see Master Bruines Hospitall
To morow consecrated by'th Cardinall,
And old Saint Marie's Spittle, here by Shoreditch.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I sister, he and you may sit 'bout what you will;
Heaven I'm sure prospers it, but I am ever crost;
You have bin bound for thee great voyages,
Yet ne're run a ground; maid, wife, and widdow,
And wife agen; have spread full and faire sayles,
No wracks you e're did dread, nor e're felt any;
But even close a shore, I'm sunke, and midst of
All my wealth made poore.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You must thanke heaven.

sp.speaker: M. Fost.
sp.l: I doe indeed, for all.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Sister, that hand can raise that gives the fall.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Master Foster, the new Sheriffe your brother
Is come to Ludgate, and I am come in haste
To know your pleasure, if you would see him.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I'l see a fury first, hence, clap to the doore I prethee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why, 'tis your brother Sir.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Father let's flye the thunder of his rage.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Stand valiantly, and let me beare the storme, all hurts
That are, and ruines in your bosomes I'l repayre.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Where's the Keeper, goe Sir, take
My Officers, and see your prisoners
Presently convey'd from Ludgate unto
Newgate, and the Counters.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Let the Constables of the Wards assist you,
Goe, dispatch and take these with you; how now,
What mak'st thou here thou Catiffe? had com'st
Thou to stitch his wounds that seekes to cut
My Throate, dar'st thou in dispight releeve this
Dotard?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Get thee from my sight, thou divell in red;
Com'st thou in scarlet pride to tread on thy poore
Brother in a Iayle, Is there but one small conduit-
pipe that runs could water to my comfort, and
Wouldst thou cut off that thou cruell man?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes, I'l stop that pipe that thou maist pining sit,
When drops but fell on me, thou poysond'st it:
Thou thrust'st a sonnes name from thy cruell brest,
For cloathing of his Vncle; now that Vncle
Shall thrust him naked forth for clothing thee,
Banisht for ever from my wealth and me.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Thou canst not be to nature so uneven,
To punish that which has a pay from heaven;
Pirty I meane, and duty; Wouldst thou strike?
Wound me then, that will kill thee if I can,
Tha'rt no brother, and I'le be no man.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou ravest.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: How can I choose? thou makest me mad,
For shame thou shouldst not make these white haires sad;
Churle, beat not my poore boy, let him not lose
Thy love for my sake, I had rather bruise
My soule with torments for a thousand yeeres, could
I but live them, rather than salt teares thy
Malice draw from him; see here's thy gold,
Tell it, none's stole, my woes can ne'r be told.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: O misery Is nature quite forgot?

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Choke with thy dung-hill muck, and vex me not.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No, keepe it, he perhaps, that money stole
From me, to give it thee, for which to vex thy
Soule, I'l turne him forth of doores, make him
Thy heire, of Iayles, miseries, curses, and dispaire;
For here I disinherit him of all.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: No matter, lands to him in heaven will fall.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Good Husband.

sp.speaker: M. Fost..
sp.l: brother.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Deare Vncle.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I am deafe.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And damn'd, the divels thumbs stop thine eares.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'l make thee wash those curses off with teares.
Keeper, away with him out of my sight,
And doe Sir, as I charg'd you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Yes Sir; I will.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Poore tyranny; when Lions weake Lambs kill.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How now wife, art vext yet?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Never so well content, beleeve me Sir;
Your mildnesse weares this maske of cruelty well.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I'm glad th'are gone, mine eyes with raine did swell,
And much adoe they had from powring downe:
The Keeper knows my minde, Wife I have paid
My brothers debts; and when he's out of doore:
To march to Newgate, he shall be set free.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O let me kisse thee for this charity;
But for your Cozin Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: He's my lives best health,
The Boy shall not miscarry for more wealth
Than London Gates looke safe up every night,
My breath in blacke clouds flyes, my thoughts
Are white.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Why from Ludgate doe you remove prisoners?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: This is my meaning wife;
I'l take the prison downe and build it new,
With Leads to walke on, Roomes large and faire:
For when my selfe lay there, the noysome ayre,
Choakt up my spirits, and none better know,
What prisoners feele, than they that taste the woe.
The workmen are appointed for the businesse,
I will ha't dispatcht before 'tis thought on.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: In good deeds I will walke hand in hand with you,
There is a faire tenement, adjoyning close to the Gate
That was my fathers, I'l give it freely, take it downe,
And adde so much ground to the worke.
'Tis fairely given.
Thy soule on prisoners prayers shall mount to heaven:
The Plummers and the Workemen have survey'd the ground
From Paddington; from whence I'l have laid pipes
Long to London to convey sweet water into Ludgate;
From fresh Springs: when charity tunes the, pipe the
Poore man sings.
How now Keeper.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: The prisoners are remov'd Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: What did you with my brother?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: As you commanded Sir, I have discharged him.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: How did he meet that unexpected kindnesse?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Troth Sir, as a man or'ecome 'twixt griefe and gladnes,
But turning to his sonne, he fetcht a sigh
So violent, as if his heart would breake,
And silent, wept, having no power to speake.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: 'Las good old man, some sweet bird must sing,
And give his sorrowes present comforting.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Not yet, I'l wracke his sorrowes to the height,
And of themselves they'l then sinke softly downe;
Keeper, goe thou agen after my brother,
Charge in my name him and his sonne to appeare
Before the King, to whom I will make knowne
Their wrongs against me; shewing just cause
To disinherit both by course of law. Be gone.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: I am gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Come Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: What's your meaning Sir?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou shall know that anon.
The heavens oft scowle, clouds thicken, winds blow high,
Yet the brightest Sunne cleares all, and so will I.

div.stage: Enter, Henry the third Mountford, Pembroke, Arundell, Lord Maior, Sheriffe Foster, Cardinall, Bruine, &c.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O! welcome is all love, our peoples shouts
In their hearts language, make our benvenues,
Most high and soveraigne; we returne all thankes
Vnto our loving Cittizens, chiefely to you Sir,
Whose pious worke invites our Majesty to royallize
This place with our best presence, accompanied with this
Reverend Cardinall; would we might, after many broyles,
End our dayes in these religious toyles;
We would worke most faithfully; but bounteous Sir,
How doe you call your buildings?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Vnlesse it please your Majesty to change it,
I call it, Domus Dei.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: The house of God, it is too good to change, pray you proceede.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: These are my ends to all distressed Christians,
Whose travailes this way bends the hospitall,
Shall free souccour be, for three dayes, and three nights
Sojourne, for dyet, and lodging, both sweet, and
Satisfying; and if their neede be such, as much in
Coyne, as shall for three dayes more defray their
Futher travaile; this unto heaven, be you
Testator, good my Liege, and witnesse with me, noble
Gentlemen, most free and faithfully, I dedicate.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An honourable worke, and deserves large memory.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: 'Tis a good example, 'tis pitty 'tis no better followed.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.p: But say Sir, now in some future age, perhaps some two or three hundred yeere behinde us, this place
sp.l: Intended for a use so charitable, should bee
Vnhallowed agen, by villanous inhabitants; say whores,
In the stead of christians, and your hospitable
Tenements, turn'd into stewes; would not this grieve
You in your grave?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: If my grave were capable of griefe: sure it would Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Prethee be a false Prophet.

sp.speaker: Arun.
sp.l: I will, if I can, my Lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let now our Heraulds in the streets proclaime,
The title, and office, of this hospitall;
Make knowne to all distressed travellors, that
We'le accept this charitable house, this Domus Dei:
Shall be their free sojourne, as is propos'd.

div.stage: Enter the one way, Stephens wife, the other, Mistris Foster, Iane, Old Foster, Robert and Keeper, All kneele.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What are these peticioners?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Each hath a knee for duty, the other for petition,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Rise, your dutie's done, your petitions shall neede
No knees, so your intents be honest, does
None here know them?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yes my good Lord, there's now a wonder in your sight.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A wonder, Master Sheriffe, you meane for beauty.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No my Lege, I would not so boast mine
Owne wife, but 'tis a wonder that excels beauty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A wonder in a woman; What is't I prethee?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Patience my Leige, this is a woman that
Was never vext.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You may boast it largely; 'tis a subjects happinesse
Above a Queenes; Have you suites to us?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: I am the suppliant plaintiffe, royall Henry
From me their griefes take their originall.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Even what your Grace shall please to make of me;
I was the son to this distressed father, untill he
Tooke his paternity off, and threw me from his love,
Then I became son to mine Vncle by adoption,
Who likewise that hath tane away againe,
And throwne me backe to poverty; never was
Son so tost betwixt two fathers, yet knowes
Not one, for still the richest does despise his heire,
And I am backe expulst into despaire.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This may your vices cause.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: For that I come to your impartiall censure for a doome.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We heare, speake on, we know the parties,
Each one relate his griefe, and if it lye in us,
We'l yeeld reliefe; 'tis first requisite that we
Know of you Sir, the cause of this your Sonnes disinheritance

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: Before I understood his vertuous minde,
Or weighed his disposition to be kind,
I did that froward worke; This now great man,
Was an unthrifty wretch, a prodigall then.
And I disdain'd to know his brotherhood,
Denyed reliefe to him; this childe kinde and good
Against my contradiction, did him releive, as his
Distressed Vncle, at this I chide; for bade,
Still hee holds on his course,
He growes more kinde, and he in wasting worse;
My rage continued as it had begun,
And in that rage I threw away my sonne.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The like plead I, my Lord: for when my state
Had rais'd itselfe by an uncertaine fate,
I tooke this out-cast childe, made him my owne,
As full and free, as I my selfe had sowne
The seede that brought him forth; for this my loue,
His oblieg'd duty presently did prove
A traytor to my trust, against my will,
Succouring that foe, which I did love so ill,
Onely for hating him; my charity being thus
Abus'd, and quit with injurie, what could I then
But as his father erst, so I agen might throw
Him from my love? for worse is love abus'd
Then new borne hate, and should be soe refus'de:
I did a fathers part, if it were bad,
Blame him for both, there I my patterne had.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You fall betwixt two pillars Sir, is't not so?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: Vnhappy fate, my Lord, yet thus I pleade:
For this my fathers hate I might deserve,
I broke his precepts, and did unchildly swerve
From his commission, I to my Vncle gave
What was my fathers, striving thereby to save
His falne repute; he rag'd, I did it still,
Yet must consesse as it was well, twas ill,
Well in my love, me thought, ill to my fate:
For I thereby ruin'd my owne estate,
But that mine Vncle throwes me forth of doore
For the same cause he tooke me in before,
Beats forest, gainst my bosome; if 'twere good
To take from a father for an Vncles foode,
In lawes of love and nature, how much rather
Might I abridge an Vncle for a father?
Charitie's, a vertue generally stands,
And should dispersed be through all mens hands.
Then would you keep't alone; for when your heire
I first adopted was, charity was there:
How er'rs your judgement then? seeing you see
What was good in you, makes sin in mee;
You'l say my father did it, oh throw away
That soule excuse; let not discretion stray
So farre a side; if custome lawfull make,
Then sin were lawfull for example sake;
Nor were these wasted goods only your owne,
Since part was mine having adoption;
Then doe him right, my Lord, yet doe no wrong,
For where my duty fai'ld my love was strong.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: With an impartiall eare we have heard your
Loving story, 'tis both fayre and honest.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O let me now anticipate your Grace,
And casting off the shadow of a face,
Shew my hearts true figure, how have I striv'd
To make this forc't counterfeit long liu'd,
And now it bursts; come into my heart,
I have two iewells here shall never part
From my loves eye watch, two worthy to be fil'd,
On times best record; a woman and a child,
Now Sir, to you I come, we must be friends,
Though envie wils not so, yet love contends
Gainst envy and her forces; my young yeares
Say I must offer first, a peace in teares.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: O let my shame my bosomes center breake!
Love is so young it coyes, but cannot speake.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You blesse mine eyes with objects that become
The theater of Kings to looke upon.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: The keeper is discharg'd Sir, your debts are paid,
And from the prison yare a new free man made:
Theres not a Creditor can aske you ought,
As your sonne did forme, so have I bought
Your liberty with mine, and to encrease it more,
Because I know bare liberty is poore
Without assistance: to raise your state agen,
The thirds of mine are yours, say you Amen.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No, not to that, you are kind brothers now,
Divide by halfes that love, and I'l allow.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thou art onely wise in vertue, as thou setst downe,
So let it be, halfe my estate's your owne.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: It whole redownes agen, for I am yours;
Forget this minute my forgetfull houres.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O, they are buried all Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This union's good, such league should ever be in brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Yet without boast, my Leige, let me relate
One small thing more, remorse of my owne state,
And my deare brothers worse succession;
For that we both have prisoners been in one
Selfe-same place of woe, and felt those throwes
That Ludgate yeelds; my charity bestowes
Some almes of comfort: Keeper you can speake it.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: And many hundreds more Sir, you have reedified
And built it faire, adding more ground to it,
And by pipes of lead from Paddingtun, drawne
Water thither, free for all prisoners, lodgings
Likewise free, and a hundred pounds yearely, to make
Them fues for better comfort: all this is almost finisht:

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: A worthy work, the better being done in the Founders ere,
Not left unto succession.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: O my good Lord, I ever keep in mind an English
Sentence, which my tutor is, and teaches me to act my
Charity with mine owne hands so doubtfull is
Performance, when the Benefactor's dead.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What is't I prethee?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: This my good Lord, women are forgetfull.
Children unkind, Executors covetous, and take what they find,
If any man aske where the deads goods became,
The Executor sweares he dyed a poore man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have prevented well, so has this good Alderman,
I wish you many Schollers.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: You make some doubt of me in this Sir;
Did you not say that women were forgetfull,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have vext her now Sir, how doe you answer that?

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: No my Lord, she's exempt from the proverbe.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: No my Lord, I'l helpe it better, I doe confesse
That women are forgetfull, yet ne'r the lesse
I am exempt, I know my fate, and finde
My deare husband must not leave me behind,
But I must goe before him, and 'tis said,
The grave's good rest when women goe first to bed.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Thankes for thy excuse good wife, but not thy love
To fill my grave before me, I would not live to see that day.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Prethee no more, I had rather be angry than flatter'd.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You have a wonder Master Sheriffe, a prizelesse jewell.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: Many jewels my good Lord; a brother, wife, and child,
For this I would have strove even with a father,
How ere rough stormes did in my brows appeare,
Within my bosome it was alwaies cleare.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: I give him to you now Sir.

sp.speaker: Ste.
sp.l: I take him, and to him backe doe give,
All that my selfe behind in state shall leave.

sp.speaker: O. Fost.
sp.l: And all that you gave me, I doe bestow,
So in one houre become full heire to two.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I claime a third by this bonds vertue,
See as a third father, thou art heire to those.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I will not goe to him father on any of these conditions.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: You shall have love to boote too, sweet Iane.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: Nay, and you play booty, I dare not trust you.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.l: What shall I say, except my hand and heart,
Ty'de in a True-loves Knot, ne'r to part.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.l: I marry Sir, these are better conditions than the
Inheritance of three fathers; let me have
Love in Esse, let lands follow in Posse:
Now I'l have thee as fast as the Priest
Can dispatch us, let him read as fast as he can.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The liveliest harmony that ere I heard;
All instruments compar'd to these sweet tunes,
Are dull and harsh; I joy to see so good a childe.
A woman wonder, brothers reconcil'd;
You worthy Sir, did invite us to a feast,
Wee'l not forget it, but will bee your guest,
Because wee'l veiw these wonders o're agen,
Whose records doe deserve a brazen Pen,
But this above the rest, in golden text,
Shall be insculpt; A Woman never Vext.
